Knowledge Point: Pichi has a subject-verb word order\is{word order} in intransitive clauses (cf. \ref{ex:key:515} below), and a subject-verb-object order in transitive clauses \REF{ex:key:513}:
Content 1: \gll Di chía blák, di \textbf{chía}, \textbf{e} blák. | \gls DEF chair be.black DEF chair 3SG.SBJ be.black | \glt ‘The chair is black, the chair (it) is black.’
Content 2: \gll E sɛ́n di bɔ́l. | \gls 3SG.SBJ send DEF ball | \glt ‘She threw the ball.’

Knowledge Point: Full nouns occur on their own as subjects. But a coreferential dependent pronoun may additionally occur in the clause which picks up the definite subject. Such structures may be seen to involve topicalisation by dislocation (cf. \sectref{sec:7.5.1}). Example \REF{ex:key:515} features both alternatives:
Content 1: \gll Di chía blák, di \textbf{chía}, \textbf{e} blák. | \gls DEF chair be.black DEF chair 3SG.SBJ be.black | \glt ‘The chair is black, the chair (it) is black.’

Knowledge Point: Pronoun resumption is also found with objects{\fff}. The following two examples illustrate the use of pronominal copying with fronted and topical object NPs. In \REF{ex:key:516}, the full NP dán mán ‘that man’ and in \REF{ex:key:517} the emphatic \textsc{3pl} pronoun dɛ́n are set off from the rest of the clause by an intonation break and resumed by object pronouns:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dán} \textbf{mán}, a dɔ́n sí=\textbf{an} sɛ́f. | \gls that man 1SG.SBJ PRF see=3SG.OBJ EMP | \glt ‘That man, I have even seen him.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Dɛ́n}, a nó de pút \textbf{dɛ́n} ínsay. | \gls 3PL.INDP 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV put 3PL.INDP inside | \glt ‘As for them, I don’t put them inside.’

Knowledge Point: An indication that subject pronoun copying may also involve a topic-comment structure comes from examples such as \REF{ex:key:518}. This sentence features the independent, emphatic personal pronoun dɛ́n at the beginning of the clause, followed by a coreferential dependent pronoun:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛ́n}, \textbf{dɛn} bin de, dɛn bin dɔ́n sabí (...) | \gls 3PL.INDP 3PL PST IPFV 3PL PST PRF know (...) | \glt ‘As for them, they were, they had already found out (...)’

Knowledge Point: Constructions like \REF{ex:key:518}, in which a personal pronoun is fronted for focus or emphasis\is{emphasis} and immediately followed by a resumptive dependent personal pronoun, are, however, rare. Instead, emphatic personal pronouns appear more often on their own. This pattern suggests that subject pronoun copying is pragmatically less marked than object pronoun copying as encountered in \REF{ex:key:516} and \REF{ex:key:517}. This observation fits with the high frequency of resumptive pronoun\is{resumptive pronouns} usage in the relativised position of subject relative clause\is{relative clauses}s as compared to the lower frequency in object relative clauses (cf. \sectref{sec:10.6.2}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛ́n}, \textbf{dɛn} bin de, dɛn bin dɔ́n sabí (...) | \gls 3PL.INDP 3PL PST IPFV 3PL PST PRF know (...) | \glt ‘As for them, they were, they had already found out (...)’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Dán} \textbf{mán}, a dɔ́n sí=\textbf{an} sɛ́f. | \gls that man 1SG.SBJ PRF see=3SG.OBJ EMP | \glt ‘That man, I have even seen him.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Dɛ́n}, a nó de pút \textbf{dɛ́n} ínsay. | \gls 3PL.INDP 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV put 3PL.INDP inside | \glt ‘As for them, I don’t put them inside.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:521}, tú ‘too (much)’ occurs before the stative verb évi ‘be heavy’. In \REF{ex:key:522}, tú appears before the locative-existential copula dé:
Content 1: \gll Di bɔ́ks e \textbf{tú} \textbf{évi}. | \gls DEF box 3SG.SBJ too be.heavy | \glt ‘The box (it) is too heavy.’
Content 2: \gll Di strít \textbf{tú} \textbf{dé} wɔwɔ́. | \gls DEF street too BE.LOC ugly | \glt ‘The street is too messed up.’

Knowledge Point: Other adverbs and adverbials are usually found at the clause margins. Compare the clause-final degree adverb smɔ́l ‘a bit’ (< ‘(be) small’) in \REF{ex:key:523}:
Content 1: \gll Djunais dɔ́n dríng \textbf{smɔ́l}. | \gls NAME PRF drink a.bit | \glt ‘Djunais has drunk a bit [of alcohol].’

Knowledge Point: Two types of copula clauses should be distinguished. Equative clauses feature the focus markers na \textsc{‘foc’} and nóto \textsc{‘neg.foc’} in a copula function. I analyse na{}-copula clauses as grammaticalised topic-comment structures, in which the notional subject is topicalised, and the nominal functioning as the copula complement is under focus. These clauses differ from verbal clauses and predicate adjective clauses involving the copula dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ in two ways: Pronominal subjects are always from the emphatic series \REF{ex:key:524}, and more often than not, the \textsc{3sg} and \textsc{3pl} pronouns remain unexpressed \REF{ex:key:525} because na and nóto incorporate \textsc{3sg} reference by default:
Content 1: \gll Mí \textbf{na} di chíf nɔ́. | \gls 1SG.INDP FOC DEF chief INTJ | \glt ‘I’m the boss, right.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nóto} mecánico. | \gls NEG.FOC mechanic | \glt ‘(He’s) not a mecanic.’

Knowledge Point: Predicate adjective clauses constitute the second type of copula clause. A small set of property-denoting verbs may also function as predicate adjectives and appear as complements \is{complements}to the locative-existential copula dé \textsc{‘be.loc’} \REF{ex:key:526}. Unlike other property items, these adjectives may therefore appear in the same syntactic position as adverbials in this type of copula clause \REF{ex:key:527}:
Content 1: \gll Tidé di húman \textbf{dé} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls today DEF woman BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘Today the woman is fine.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{dé} \textbf{na} \textbf{grɔ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC LOC ground | \glt ‘He is [lying] on the ground.’

Knowledge Point: The syntax of \textsc{2sg} directive (imperative\is{imperatives}) clauses is distinct from other clause types and other directive clauses in that the \textsc{2sg} subject remains unexpressed \REF{ex:key:528}. However, a \textsc{2pl} subject must be overtly expressed \REF{ex:key:529}:
Content 1: \gll Nó \textbf{láf}! | \gls NEG laugh | \glt ‘Don’t laugh!’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Una} \textbf{púl} di torí! | \gls 2PL pull DEF story | \glt ‘Tell [PL] the story!’

Knowledge Point: Moreover, directives are the only type of main clause that feature a TMA marker in the prenominal rather than the preverbal slot; compare the subjunctive\is{subjunctive mood} marker mék ‘\textsc{sbjv}’ \REF{ex:key:530}:\is{deontic modality}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mék} a púl wán smɔ́l torí? | \gls SBJV 1SG.SBJ pull one small story | \glt ‘Should I tell a little story?’

Knowledge Point: At the same time, directive subjunctive clauses are structurally no different from other clauses that feature a clause linker at their very left. Compare \REF{ex:key:530} with the sequential clause introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’ in \REF{ex:key:531}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mék} a púl wán smɔ́l torí? | \gls SBJV 1SG.SBJ pull one small story | \glt ‘Should I tell a little story?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wé} e bin dáy só. | \gls SUB 3SG.SBJ PST die like.that | \glt ‘And he died just like that.’

Knowledge Point: The negation of declarative clauses is symmetrical. They acquire negative polarity when the general negator nó is placed before the bare verb or the relevant TMA marker. The position of the negator is canonical. The imperfective-marked verb gí ‘give’ in \REF{ex:key:532} is negated in \REF{ex:key:533}. A negative existential clause is presented in \REF{ex:key:534}. Note the appearance of negative concord in the latter example:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn de \textbf{gí} dɛ́n skúl fɔ training centre. | \gls 3PL IPFV give 3PL.INDP school PREP training centre | \glt ‘They give them classes at a training centre.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{nó} de \textbf{gí} \textbf{nó} nátín. | \gls 3PL NEG IPFV give NEG nothing | \glt ‘They don’t give anything.’
Content 3: \gll Láyf \textbf{nó} \textbf{dé} náw, wɔ́l \textbf{nó} \textbf{dé}. | \gls life NEG BE.LOC now world NEG BE.LOC | \glt ‘[Nowadays] there is no life, there is no (proper) world.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:535} contains both an affirmative and a negative clause in the potential mood. The two subsequent examples present an affirmative clause marked for past tense\is{past tense} and its negative counterpart (\ref{ex:key:536}-\ref{ex:key:537}).
Content 1: \gll Ho, dán mán \textbf{go} dú vɔ́mit tidé, e \textbf{nó} \textbf{go} slíp. | \gls INTJ that man POT do vomit today 3SG.SBJ NEG POT sleep | \glt ‘That man is going to vomit today, he won’t sleep.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{bin} dé na jél. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PST BE.LOC LOC jail | \glt ‘He was in jail.’
Content 3: \gll A \textbf{nó} \textbf{bin} fít ték motó. | \gls 1SG.SBJ NEG PST can take car | \glt ‘I wasn’t able to take a car.’

Knowledge Point: Imperatives \REF{ex:key:538} are negated either with a symmetrical structure \REF{ex:key:539} or with an asymmetrical structure involving a negative subjunctive\is{subjunctive mood} clause \REF{ex:key:540}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pás} na mákit mɔ́! | \gls pass LOC market again | \glt ‘Pass by the market again!’
Content 2: \gll Nó, wi de conversa, \textbf{nó} \textbf{vɛ́ks} Djunais! | \gls NEG 1PL IPFV converse NEG be.angry NAME | \glt ‘No, we’re (just) conversing, don’t be angry Djunais!’
Content 3: Not found

Knowledge Point: The negation of the perfect tense-aspect is asymmetrical. While the affirmative features the marker dɔ́n ‘\textsc{prf}’ \REF{ex:key:541}, the negative perfect is formed with a suppletive allomorph, i.e. either of the free variants nɛ́a and nɔ́ba ‘\textsc{neg.prf}’ \REF{ex:key:542}:
Content 1: \gll Yu \textbf{dɔ́n} bɔ́n fo pikín, (...) | \gls 2SG PRF give.birth four child (...) | \glt ‘You have given birth to four children, (...)’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{nɛ́a} \textbf{bɔ́n} pikín. | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG.PRF give.birth child | \glt ‘She hasn’t given birth to a child yet.’

Knowledge Point: The adverbial yét ‘still, yet’ may appear with the negative perfect without providing an additional meaning besides stressing the nuance of current relevance inherent to the perfect \REF{ex:key:543}. However, the combination nó -- yét ‘not yet’ can also express this nuance of the perfect by itself and thereby function as a de facto negative perfect marker \REF{ex:key:544}. In an affirmative clause, the adverbial yét means ‘yet, still’, as in \REF{ex:key:247} in \sectref{sec:5.2.3}.
Content 1: \gll Yu sísta e \textbf{nɔ́ba} máred \textbf{yét}? | \gls 2SG sister 3SG.SBJ NEG.PRF marry yet | \glt ‘Your sister isn’t married yet?’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{nó} máred \textbf{yét}? | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG marry yet | \glt ‘She isn’t married yet?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Sɔn} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{di} \textbf{watá} dé yét. | \gls some PREP DEF water BE.LOC yet | \glt ‘Some of the water still remains.’

Knowledge Point: The two other combinations of verb negation and a clause-final adverbial are nó -- mɔ́ ‘no more, not again’ and nó -- sɛ́f ‘not even’. Compare the affirmative use of mɔ́ ‘more’ in \REF{ex:key:538} with \REF{ex:key:545} below.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pás} na mákit mɔ́! | \gls pass LOC market again | \glt ‘Pass by the market again!’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{nó} go fláy na Bata \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls 3PL NEG POT fly LOC PLACE more | \glt ‘They’re not going to fly to Bata anymore/again.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:key:546} and \REF{ex:key:547} present the use of sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ in an affirmative and a negative clause, respectively. The negated clause acquires an emphatic negative meaning:
Content 1: \gll Náw e dɔ́n dáy \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls now 3SG.SBJ PRF die EMP | \glt ‘Now he is even dead.’
Content 2: \gll Ɛ́n, dɛn \textbf{nó} nó \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls INTJ 3PL NEG know EMP | \glt ‘Yes, they don’t even know (at all).’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:549}, the plural subject mán dɛn ‘people’ and the singular subject chɔ́p ‘food’ are both not preceded by nó ‘\textsc{neg}’. The noun chɔ́p is the subject of a negative existential clause. Such clauses usually only feature negative concord when extra emphasis\is{emphasis} is desired \REF{ex:key:551}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mán} \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{nó} de bísin fɔ mék fám mɔ́, yu gó fɔ mákit, \textbf{chɔ́p} \textbf{nó} dé. | \gls man PL NEG IPFV be.busy PREP make farm more 2SG go PREP market food NEG BE.LOC | \glt ‘People don’t care about farming anymore, (if) you go to the market there’s no food.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{motó} \textbf{nó} dé wé e smát lɛk mi yón. | \gls NEG car NEG BE.LOC SUB 3SG.SBJ be.fast like 1SG.POSS own | \glt ‘There is not a single car that is as fast as mine.’

Knowledge Point: Subject \textsc{NPs} may nevertheless be preceded by nó. Such negative clauses featuring negative concord have a single negation reading. Negative concord provides a means of adding an emphatic sense to the negative clause. Compare dɔ́kta ‘doctor’ in \REF{ex:key:550} and motó ‘car’ in \REF{ex:key:551}:
Content 1: \gll E sé bueno ás \textbf{nó} \textbf{dɔ́kta} \textbf{nó} de kán sí (...) | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT good as NEG doctor NEG IPFV come see (...) | \glt ‘She said, ok, since no doctor is at all coming to see (...)’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{motó} \textbf{nó} dé wé e smát lɛk mi yón. | \gls NEG car NEG BE.LOC SUB 3SG.SBJ be.fast like 1SG.POSS own | \glt ‘There is not a single car that is as fast as mine.’

Knowledge Point: Object NPs also only feature negative concord when emphasis is intended. Compare the non-emphatic negative clause in \REF{ex:key:552} with \REF{ex:key:553}. The use of negative concord in \REF{ex:key:553} gives an emphatic meaning to the object problema `problem'. Also note the presence of the independent emphatic pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’ \REF{ex:key:553}:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{nó} gɛ́t pamáyn. | \gls 1SG.SBJ NEG get oil | \glt ‘I don’t have (any) oil.’
Content 2: \gll \'{I}n go chɔ́p=an, e \textbf{nó} gɛ́t \textbf{nó} problema. | \gls 3SG.INDP POT eat=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ NEG get NEG problem | \glt ‘He [EMP] will eat it, he has no problem whatsoever [with this kind of food].’
Content 3: \gll \'{I}n go chɔ́p=an, e \textbf{nó} gɛ́t \textbf{nó} problema. | \gls 3SG.INDP POT eat=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ NEG get NEG problem | \glt ‘He [EMP] will eat it, he has no problem whatsoever [with this kind of food].’
Content 4: \gll \'{I}n go chɔ́p=an, e \textbf{nó} gɛ́t \textbf{nó} problema. | \gls 3SG.INDP POT eat=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ NEG get NEG problem | \glt ‘He [EMP] will eat it, he has no problem whatsoever [with this kind of food].’

Knowledge Point: Often, emphasis\is{emphasis} comes in combination with other emphatic features, i.e. suprasegmental cues such as increased volume, higher pitch, or reduced speed in the pronunciation of the negator and the negated \textsc{NP,} or the use of emphatic elements. NPs preceded by nó in negative clauses can receive an even higher degree of emphasis if the negative quantifier nó is followed by the cardinal numeral and indefinite determiner wán, as in \REF{ex:key:554} with the object wɔ́d ‘word’:
Content 1: \gll Sóté a \textbf{nó} tɔ́k \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} wɔ́d. | \gls until 1SG.SBJ NEG talk NEG one word | \glt ‘Until I didn’t say a single word (anymore).’

Knowledge Point: Negative concord is also found in coordinate \textsc{NPs} featuring the negative coordinator pair ni -- ni, which is borrowed\is{borrowing} from \ili{Spanish} \REF{ex:key:555}. Spanish employs no negative concord in this particular construction \REF{ex:key:556}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ni} ín \textbf{ni} in brɔ́da dɛn \textbf{nó} lán. | \gls NEG 3SG.INDP NEG 3SG.POSS brother 3PL NEG learn | \glt ‘Neither he nor his brothers (have) studied.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ni} él \textbf{ni} su hermano han estudiado. | \gls NEG he NEG his brother have studied | \glt ‘Neither he nor his brother has studied.’

Knowledge Point: In verbal clauses, the negative indefinite pronoun nátin must be used with a preceding negative quantifier nó ‘\textsc{neg’} as well as with support from verb negation. This holds for both the subject and object position. Since nátin is inherently negative, its use in verbal clauses therefore invariably involves the use of double negative concord. Compare the indefinite \textsc{NP} sɔn tín ‘something’ \REF{ex:key:557} with the subject and object negative indefinite pronoun nátin ‘nothing’ in \REF{ex:key:558} and \REF{ex:key:559} respectively:
Content 1: \gll Mí wánt aks yú \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{tín}. | \gls 1SG.INDP want ask 2SG.INDP some thing | \glt ‘I want to ask you something.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Mí \textbf{nó} go tɛ́l=an \textbf{nó} \textbf{nátín}. | \gls 1SG.INDP NEG POT tell=3SG.OBJ NEG nothing | \glt ‘I [EMP] wouldn’t tell him anything.’

Knowledge Point: The negative indefinite phrase nó mán ‘\textsc{neg} man’ = ‘nobody’ is equally common as nó bɔ́di ‘nobody’ (\ref{ex:key:561}–\ref{ex:key:562}). The third logical alternative, nó pɔ́sin ‘\textsc{neg} person’ = ‘nobody’, is rare in the data:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{mán} \textbf{nó} blánt yá mɔ́ sɛ́f. | \gls NEG man NEG reside here more EMP | \glt ‘Nobody even lives here anymore.’

Knowledge Point: The affirmative counterparts of the negative indefinite phrases in (\ref{ex:key:561}–\ref{ex:key:562}) are indefinite (quantifier) phrases involving pɔ́sin ‘person’ and mán ‘man’, which function as indefinite pronouns:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{mán} \textbf{nó} blánt yá mɔ́ sɛ́f. | \gls NEG man NEG reside here more EMP | \glt ‘Nobody even lives here anymore.’

Knowledge Point: The adverbial concept ‘never’ is expressed via the phrase nó wán dé ‘\textsc{neg} one day’ \REF{ex:key:570}. Example \REF{ex:key:569} features the equivalent affirmative phrase ɔ́l tɛ́n ‘all time’ = ‘always’:
Content 1: \gll E sé \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé} e \textbf{nó} go dú=an mɔ́. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT NEG one day 3SG.SBJ NEG POT do=3SG.OBJ more | \glt ‘He said he would never do it again.’
Content 2: \gll Di húman \textbf{ɔ́l} \textbf{tɛ́n} e dé fáyn. | \gls DEF woman all time 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘The woman is always looking fine.’

Knowledge Point: The negative pronominal meaning of ‘none, any’ may be expressed through verb negation and use of the quantifier\is{quantifiers} and indefinite determiner sɔn ‘some, a’, which may refer to count and mass nouns alike. The affirmative clause in \REF{ex:key:571} features sɔn used as pronominal (cf. also \ref{ex:key:186}–\ref{ex:key:187}). The negative counterpart of \REF{ex:key:571} may simply be a negative clause \REF{ex:key:572}:
Content 1: \gll Dán banána, a gí=an \textbf{sɔn}. | \gls that banana 1SG.SBJ give=3SG.OBJ some | \glt ‘That banana, I gave him one.’
Content 2: \gll Na só mi yón sɛ́f, a jɔ́s báy \textbf{sɔn}. | \gls FOC like.that 1SG.POSS own EMP 1SG.SBJ just buy some | \glt ‘That’s how it is with me as well, I just bought one [a TV set].’
Content 3: \gll A gɛ́t \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{dɛn}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ get some PL | \glt ‘I have some (PL).’
Content 4: \gll Dán banána, a gí=an \textbf{sɔn}. | \gls that banana 1SG.SBJ give=3SG.OBJ some | \glt ‘That banana, I gave him one.’
Content 5: \gll A \textbf{nó} gɛ́t \textbf{sɔn}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ NEG get some | \glt ‘I don’t have some/any.’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, the negative indefinite phrase nó wán, which features the noun substitute wán ‘one’ may be employed when the referent is a count noun or an individuated entity \REF{ex:key:573}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{wán} \textbf{nó} lɛ́f wet mí. | \gls NEG one NEG remain with 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘None (at all) remains with me.’

Knowledge Point: The use of nó wán in such contexts often has emphatic connotations. Accordingly, the cardinal numeral wán also appears between the negator nó and a noun in emphatic negative phrases like \REF{ex:key:574} and \REF{ex:key:575}. This usage also corresponds to the use of wán as an emphatic indefinite determiner in other contexts (e.g. with nouns under cleft focus in presentatives (cf. \ref{ex:key:179}):
Content 1: \gll A go tɛ́l=an sé a nó de sɛ́l \textbf{nó} teléfono, \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ POT tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV sell NEG telephone NEG one | \glt ‘I’ll tell her that I’m not going to sell any telephone, none (at all).’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} tɔ́k \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} wɔ́d! | \gls NEG talk NEG one word | \glt ‘Don’t say a single word!’
Content 3: \gll E dé complicado, \textbf{na} \textbf{wán} \textbf{tín} \textbf{dat}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC complicated FOC one thing that | \glt ‘It’s complicated, it’s one (kind of a) thing.’

Knowledge Point: The fixed expression nó wán dé ‘never’ in \REF{ex:key:570} above is also such an emphatic negative phrase, even if lexicalised.\is{negative phrases}
Content 1: \gll E sé \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé} e \textbf{nó} go dú=an mɔ́. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT NEG one day 3SG.SBJ NEG POT do=3SG.OBJ more | \glt ‘He said he would never do it again.’

Knowledge Point: Cleft focus provides a means of negating single constituents and is possible with any constituent that may be focused (cf. \sectref{sec:7.4.3.2}). In cleft focus constructions, the focused element is fronted to the sentence-initial position and preceded by the negative focus marker nóto ‘\textsc{neg}.\textsc{foc}’. Compare \REF{ex:key:576}, where the subject \textsc{NP} ɔ́l húman ‘all women’ is singled out for constituent negation:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nóto} \textbf{ɔ́l} \textbf{húman} fít máred. | \gls NEG.FOC all woman can marry | \glt ‘Not all women can get married.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbials are negated in the same way as core \textsc{NPs}. Example \REF{ex:key:577} features the negated time adverbial tidé ‘today’, \REF{ex:key:578} the reason adverbial fɔ dán tín:
Content 1: \gll Ɛ́n, \textbf{na} \textbf{tidé} mí híɛ. | \gls INTJ FOC today 1SG.INDP hear | \glt ‘Yes, it’s today that I [EMP] heard (it).’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nóto} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{dán} \textbf{tín} yu de kráy? | \gls FOC PREP that thing 2SG IPFV cry | \glt ‘Is it not because of that that you are crying?’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:579}, the speaker abbreviated as (hi) complains about the discrimination of women in wedlock, a condition she likens to slavery. In the example, speaker (hi) first negates the direct quote e fíba ‘it resembles’, the second nóto negates the verbal constituent as such:
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́, \textbf{nóto} “e fíba,” na esclavitud, \textbf{nóto} “fíba”. | \gls INTJ NEG.FOC 3SG.SBJ resemble FOC slavery NEG.FOC seem | \glt ‘Yes, not “it resembles (slavery)”, it’s slavery, not “resemble”.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:key:580} and \REF{ex:key:581} illustrate how yet larger sentence constituents can be singled out for negation. Both examples are negative factive clauses, in which the existence of the situation of the reference clause is negated:
Content 1: \gll Ɛf \textbf{nóto} \textbf{yu} \textbf{bay}, dán húman go bít yú sóté yu go gó lɛ́f=an. | \gls if NEG.FOC 2SG buy that woman POT beat 2SG.INDP until 2SG POT go leave=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘If it wasn’t the case that you had bought (it), that woman would beat you until you’d go and leave it there.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nóto} \textbf{sé} na hɔ́s dɛn fɔ fɔ́s tɛ́n wé dɛn strɔ́n, e fɔ dɔ́n fɔdɔ́n. | \gls NEG.FOC QUOT FOC house PL PREP first time SUB 3PL be.strong 3SG.SBJ PREP PRF fall | \glt ‘(If) it wasn’t the case that they were houses of the past that are strong, it would have already collapsed.’

Knowledge Point: Multiple core \REF{ex:key:589} and adverbial \REF{ex:key:590} \textsc{NP}s forming part of coordinate structures may also be questioned. These two examples also show that in principle, a sentence may contain several question elements, even if this is rare in natural speech:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}dat} \textbf{wet} \textbf{wétin} de hambɔ́g yú? | \gls who with what IPFV bother 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘Who and what is bothering you?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=sáy} \textbf{wet} \textbf{háw} yu de wás? | \gls Q=side with how 2SG IPFV wash | \glt ‘Where and how are you washing?’

Knowledge Point: Question elements may occur in situ in the original position of the questioned element, or they may be fronted. Questioned subjects naturally occur at the beginning of the clause as shown in \REF{ex:key:589}. They may also optionally be focused in cleft constructions \REF{ex:key:591}\is{cleft constructions}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}dat} \textbf{wet} \textbf{wétin} de hambɔ́g yú? | \gls who with what IPFV bother 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘Who and what is bothering you?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{údat} hambɔ́g dɛ́n? | \gls FOC who bother 3PL.INDP | \glt ‘Who bothered them?’

Knowledge Point: Objects\is{objects} can be questioned in situ (e.g. údat dɛn and ús=pɔ́sin dɛn in \ref{ex:key:585} and \ref{ex:key:586} above) or be fronted \REF{ex:key:592}. Fronted objects may also optionally be cleft-focused \REF{ex:key:593}:
Content 1: \gll Yu sí \textbf{údat} \textbf{dɛn}? | \gls 2SG see who PL | \glt ‘Who [plural] did you see?’
Content 2: \gll Yu sí \textbf{ús=pɔ́sin} \textbf{dɛn}? | \gls 2SG see Q=person PL | \glt ‘Who [plural] did you see?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=tín} yu tɔ́k mɔ́ sɛ́f? | \gls Q=thing 2SG talk again EMP | \glt ‘What did you say again?’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{ús=káyn} \textbf{tín} dɛn \textbf{ték} mék dís, digamos dí bɔ́tul? | \gls FOC Q=kind thing 3PL take make this let’s.say this bottle | \glt ‘What’s, let’s say this bottle, made of?’

Knowledge Point: The objects of prepositions may also be questioned in situ or be fronted. When fronted, either the entire prepositional phrase appears at the beginning of the clause, or the preposition is stranded. However, stranding\is{stranding} in questions is only attested with fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ \REF{ex:key:594}, wet ‘with’ \REF{ex:key:595}, and pan ‘on’ \REF{ex:key:596}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wétin} yu wánt sabí \textbf{fɔ}? | \gls what 2SG want know PREP | \glt ‘What do you want to know for?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=mán} yu bin de tɔ́k \textbf{wet} yɛ́stadé? | \gls Q=man 2SG PST IPFV talk with yesterday | \glt ‘Who were you talking with yesterday?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=béd} yu kin slíp \textbf{pan}? | \gls Q=bed 2SG HAB sleep on | \glt ‘Which bed do you usually sleep on?’

Knowledge Point: All constituents that may be questioned in main clauses can also be replaced by question elements in subordinate clauses. Non-subject constituents of subordinate clauses can be questioned in situ \REF{ex:key:597} or be fronted \REF{ex:key:598}:
Content 1: \gll Yu tɔ́k sé Pancho de yús \textbf{údat} \textbf{in} \textbf{motó}? | \gls 2SG talk QUOT NAME IPFV use who 3SG.POSS car | \glt ‘You said that Pancho uses whose car?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=tín} yu tɔ́k sé yu wánt \textbf{sabí}? | \gls Q=thing 2SG talk QUOT 2SG want know | \glt ‘What did you say you wanted to know?’

Knowledge Point: Complement or adverbial clauses introduced by sé ‘\textsc{quot}’ are questioned like nominal constituents. The question word is, however, always found in situ as in the rhetorical question in \REF{ex:key:599}. Here a cause clause \is{cause clauses}is questioned by means of the phrase sé wétin ‘\textsc{quot} what’ = ‘because of what’:
Content 1: \gll A go púl=an na mi yáy \textbf{sé} \textbf{wétin}? | \gls 1SG.SBJ POT remove=3SG.OBJ LOC 1SG.POSS eye QUOT what | \glt ‘I would remove it [the pair of sunglasses] from my eyes for what?’

Knowledge Point: Questioned subjects\is{subjects} naturally occur at the beginning of the question clause, as in \REF{ex:key:591} above. Questioned objects\is{objects} appear at the beginning of the sentence \REF{ex:key:600}, or in their original position \REF{ex:key:601}. These two examples feature the question word wétin ‘\textsc{what’}, which is used for questioning inanimate entities:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{údat} hambɔ́g dɛ́n? | \gls FOC who bother 3PL.INDP | \glt ‘Who bothered them?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wétin} yu wánt \textbf{nó}? | \gls what 2SG want know | \glt ‘What do you want to know?’
Content 3: \gll Yu wánt \textbf{nó} \textbf{wétin}? | \gls 2SG want know what | \glt ‘You want to know what?’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:602} illustrates the questioning of a complex object NP. The dislocated possessive construction{\fff} údat in motó ‘whose car’ is the object of yús ‘use’ and under focus with the focus particle na. The questioning of a possessor NP is also achieved by circumlocution with the verb gɛ́t ‘get, have’ \REF{ex:key:603}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{údat} \textbf{in} \textbf{motó} Pancho de yús? | \gls FOC who 3SG.POSS car NAME IPFV use | \glt ‘It’s whose car Pancho is using?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{údat} gɛ́t dís búk? | \gls FOC who get this book | \glt ‘Who possesses this book?’

Knowledge Point: Both examples involve the question word údat ‘\textsc{who’}, which is used for questioning human referents. In a minority of cases, the concept ‘\textsc{who’} is also expressed by the bimorphemic question words ús=pɔ́sin ‘\textsc{q}=person’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:586} above) and ús=mán ‘\textsc{q}=man’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:595} above) in all relevant syntactic positions:
Content 1: \gll Yu sí \textbf{ús=pɔ́sin} \textbf{dɛn}? | \gls 2SG see Q=person PL | \glt ‘Who [plural] did you see?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=mán} yu bin de tɔ́k \textbf{wet} yɛ́stadé? | \gls Q=man 2SG PST IPFV talk with yesterday | \glt ‘Who were you talking with yesterday?’

Knowledge Point: The clitic question element ús=\textsc{q} may combine with the pronominal and noun substitute wán ‘one’ in order to render the concept ‘\textsc{which} \textsc{one’.} The collocation may be used to selectively question any noun \REF{ex:key:604}. \textit{\'{U}s=wán} is also employed in an idiomatic question clause in order to ask for a person’s name \REF{ex:key:605}. The latter usage is conventionalised and very likely to be a calque\is{borrowing} from the equivalent Spanish phrase ¿cuál es tú nombre? ‘which (one) is your name’ = ‘what’s your name?’:
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́, dán wán min sé \textbf{ús=wán} na di escala? | \gls exactly that one mean QUOT Q=one LOC DEF scale | \glt ‘Exactly, that means which one [of the two] is the scale?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=wán} na in ném? | \gls Q=one FOC 3SG.POSS NAME | \glt ‘What’s his name?’

Knowledge Point: A similar syntactic flexibility is characteristic of the objects of V2 minor (i.e. closed class) verbs in SVCs. The questioned object of pás ‘(sur)pass’ in the comparative SVC{\fff} in \REF{ex:key:606} and the object of kɛ́r ‘carry, take’ in the motion-direction SVC in \REF{ex:key:607} may be found in the original syntactic position:
Content 1: \gll E bíg \textbf{pás} \textbf{údat}? | \gls 3SG.SBJ big pass who | \glt ‘He is bigger than who?’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn kɛ́r di motó \textbf{gó} \textbf{ús=sáy}? | \gls 3PL carry DEF car go where | \glt ‘Where did they take the car to?’

Knowledge Point: At the same time, the questioning of the instrument or material objects of ték ‘take’ in participant-introducing SVCs is characterised by some idiosyncracies. Firstly, speakers seem to prefer to front the questioned object rather than leave it in the original syntactic position between ték ‘take’ and the following major verb (i.e. bíl ‘build’ in the following example). Compare \REF{ex:key:610}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=káyn} plɛ́nk dɛn \textbf{ték} bíl di hós? | \gls Q=kind board 3PL take build DEF house | \glt ‘What (kind of) board did they build the house with?’

Knowledge Point: Secondly, we find double marking of the instrument objects of ték ‘take’ as a rather regular way of questioning these objects. In \REF{ex:key:611}, the object of ték (i.e. ús=tín ‘what’) is fronted and focused. The question word and object ús=tín is additionally preceded by the instrumental/comitative preposition wet ‘with’ as if the corresponding declarative clause had been something ungrammatical like *dɛn ték wet plɛ́nk bíl di hós ‘\textsc{3pl} take with board build \textsc{def} house’ = *‘they took with board to build the house’ (cf. also \ref{ex:key:1571}–\ref{ex:key:1572}):
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{wet} \textbf{ús=tín} dɛn \textbf{ték} bíl di hós? | \gls FOC with Q=thing 3PL take build DEF house | \glt ‘With what did they build the house?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wet} ús=káyn tín dɛn \textbf{ték} \textbf{bíl} di hós? | \gls with Q=kind thing 3PL take build DEF house | \glt ‘(With) what did they build the house with?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Wet} ús=káyn stík yu bin \textbf{ték} \textbf{bíl} di hós? | \gls with Q=kind wood 2SG PST take build DEF house | \glt ‘(With) what kind of wood did you build the house with?’

Knowledge Point: However, fronting\is{fronting} of the patient object of the major (open class) verb in ték SVCs is not accepted \REF{ex:key:612}. Patients are usually questioned in situ in their original syntactic position following the major verb \REF{ex:key:613}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{ték} stón \textbf{bíl} \textbf{ús=káyn} \textbf{hós}? | \gls 3PL take stone build Q=kind house | \glt ‘Which house did they build of stone?’

Knowledge Point: Modifiers and demonstratives\is{demonstratives} in \textsc{NPs} are questioned via three question elements: the clitic ús= ‘\textsc{q}, \textsc{which’}; the (marginally employed) phonologically independent question word wích ‘w\textsc{hich’,} and the bimorphemic question word ús=káyn ‘\textsc{q}=kind’. Quantifier\is{quantifiers}s are questioned by means of háw mɔ́ch ‘how much’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:636}–\ref{ex:key:638} below). The element ús= straddles the boundary of a more functional and a more lexical meaning. Consider the translations of the following two examples, which contrast the rarely used and more lexical wích ‘\textsc{which}’ with the high-frequency question particle ús= ‘\textsc{q’}:
Content 1: \gll Yu bin sté \textbf{háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{dé}? | \gls 2SG PST stay how much day | \glt ‘How many days did you stay?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{pikín} de gó na dán skúl? | \gls how much child IPFV go LOC that school | \glt ‘How many children go to that school.’

Knowledge Point: However, questions like \REF{ex:key:616} and \REF{ex:key:617} are equally often formed by employing the question word ús=káyn ‘\textsc{q}=kind’ instead of ús= alone. The meaning of ús=káyn therefore also vacillates between a more literal sense, in which the pronominal and generic noun káyn ‘kind’ retains its lexical meaning of ‘kind’, and a more functional one, in which the entire question word ús=káyn is equivalent to ús=, ‘\textsc{q,} \textsc{which’.} This ambiguity in the meaning of káyn ‘kind’ is reflected in the translations of the following two examples:\is{cliticisation}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=nɔ́mba} yu gɛ́t fɔ dán móvil? | \gls which=number 2SG get PREP that mobile | \glt ‘Which number do you have in that mobile phone?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=nésɔn}? | \gls which=nation | \glt ‘Which people [does he belong to]?’

Knowledge Point: The more functional use of ús=káyn is more obvious when it precedes a generic noun as in the following two examples. Here, the phrase ús=káyn tín ‘\textsc{q}=kind thing’ has the same meanings as wétin or ús=tín ‘\textsc{what’}. Note that \REF{ex:key:620} is a free relative clause\is{relative clauses} and sentence \REF{ex:key:621} an indirect question. The long forms featuring káyn ‘kind’ are equally common in this position as are the shorter forms wétin and ús=tín:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta a nó sabí \textbf{ús=káyn} tín kán pás. | \gls then 1SG.SBJ NEG know Q=kind thing PFV pass | \glt ‘Then, I don’t know what happened.’
Content 2: \gll Yu nó wet \textbf{ús=káyn} tín dɛn mék dís tín? | \gls 2SG know with Q=kind thing 3PL make this thing | \glt ‘Do you know with what this is made?’

Knowledge Point: The same, more functional use can be observed when ús=káyn precedes the generic noun stáyl ‘style, manner’ in order to question an adverbial of manner (cf. \ref{ex:key:629}–\ref{ex:key:630} below). However, ús=káyn is not found in conjunction with human-denoting generic nouns like mán ‘man’ or pɔ́sin ‘person’ with the meaning of ‘\textsc{who’.}
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{ús=káyn} \textbf{stáyl} yu ték kán na yá? | \gls FOC Q=kind style 2SG take come LOC here | \glt ‘By which means did you come here?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=káyn} \textbf{stáyl} yu rích yá? | \gls Q=kind style 2SG reach here | \glt ‘By which means did you get here?’

Knowledge Point: In the same vein, time units of the day are often questioned by the more specific bimorphemic question word ús=áwa ‘\textsc{q}=hour’ \REF{ex:key:626}, which may refer to units of the clock as well as periods of the day (e.g. mɔ́nin tɛ́n ‘morning’, sán tɛ́n ‘noon’, nɛ́t ‘night’):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=áwa} yu rích? | \gls Q=hour 2SG reach | \glt ‘When [at what period of the day, at what time] did you arrive?’

Knowledge Point: The generic nouns sáy ‘side, place’ (pervasive) and pát \textit{\textup{‘part, place’} }(marginal) combine with ús= ‘\textsc{q}’ in order to render ‘\textsc{where’} and question locative adverbials\is{locative adverbials}. The question word ús=sáy tends to have a more general meaning than ús=pát ‘\textsc{q}=part, place’. The logical option ús=plés ‘\textsc{q}=place’ is accepted in elicitation but not attested in natural speech. Compare \REF{ex:key:627} and \REF{ex:key:628}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=sáy} yu kɔmɔ́t? | \gls Q=side 2SG come.out | \glt ‘Where do you come from?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=pát} yu kɔmɔ́t? | \gls Q=part 2SG come.out | \glt ‘Where do you come from?’ or ‘Which place do you come from?’

Knowledge Point: The bimorphemic question word ús=káyn ‘\textsc{which’} is also employed as a modifier of the generic noun stáyl ‘style’ in order to question manner adverbials (\ref{ex:key:629}–\ref{ex:key:630}). Note the subtle difference in meaning between ús=káyn stáyl ‘by which means’ in the following examples and háw ‘how’ further below:
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{ús=káyn} \textbf{stáyl} yu ték kán na yá? | \gls FOC Q=kind style 2SG take come LOC here | \glt ‘By which means did you come here?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=káyn} \textbf{stáyl} yu rích yá? | \gls Q=kind style 2SG reach here | \glt ‘By which means did you get here?’

Knowledge Point: A second and equally common means of questioning manner adverbials is provided by the monomorphemic question word háw ‘how’. Sentence \REF{ex:key:631} involves a main clause, example \REF{ex:key:632} a main and a subordinate clause:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Háw} e bin só, \textbf{háw} e bigín, \textbf{háw} e salút yú? | \gls how 3SG.SBJ PST show how 3SG.SBJ begin how 3SG.SBJ greet 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘How did he show [respect], how did he begin, how did he greet you?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Háw} yu sabí sé na rubio? | \gls how 2SG know QUOT FOC blond | \glt ‘How do you know it’s light?’

Knowledge Point: In addition, háw may precede the quantifier\is{quantifiers} mɔ́ch ‘much’ and form an independent question word in order to question a quantity \REF{ex:key:633} as well as the degree to which the property denoted by the property item applies (\ref{ex:key:634}–\ref{ex:key:635}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} dís sɔ́t \textbf{kɔ́s}? | \gls how much this shirt cost | \glt ‘How much did this shirt cost?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{lɔ́n}? | \gls how much be.long | \glt ‘How long?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} dí tín \textbf{évi}? | \gls how much this thing be.heavy | \glt ‘How heavy is this thing?’

Knowledge Point: The collocation háw mɔ́ch is also used to question quantifiers of count and mass nouns alike. Compare \REF{ex:key:636} in which a time quantity (hence duration) is questioned, \REF{ex:key:637} in which a mass nouns is questioned, and \REF{ex:key:638} in which the count noun pikín ‘child’ is questioned:
Content 1: \gll Yu bin sté \textbf{háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{dé}? | \gls 2SG PST stay how much day | \glt ‘How many days did you stay?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{wɔtá} yu wánt? | \gls how much water 2SG want | \glt ‘How much water do you want?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Háw} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{pikín} de gó na dán skúl? | \gls how much child IPFV go LOC that school | \glt ‘How many children go to that school.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbials of cause can be questioned in a number of ways. Firstly wétin and ús=tín ‘\textsc{what’} regularly occur with the meaning of ‘\textsc{why}’ \REF{ex:key:639}. The use of these two question words may colour the question with reproach if the subject of the clause is human:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wétin} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls what 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘Why [how come] come you’re not working today?’

Knowledge Point: Wétin and ús=tín ’what’ also occur in question phrases as the objects\is{objects} of prepositions that may mark NPs for a cause semantic role (cf. \sectref{sec:9.1.3} for details). In \REF{ex:key:642}, wétin is the object of fɔ \textsc{‘prep’}, in \REF{ex:key:643}, wet ‘with’ is followed by ús=tín , and in \REF{ex:key:644}, the preposition fɔséka ‘due to’ takes ús=tín as its object. The resulting phrases all serve to question adverbials of cause. Note that these phrases can optionally appear under cleft-focus like any other question element: \is{cleft constructions}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fɔ} \textbf{wétin} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls PREP what 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘Why aren’t you working today?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{wet} \textbf{ús=tín} in pikín dáy, ús=sík? | \gls FOC with Q=thing 3SG.POSS child die Q=sickness | \glt ‘Due to what did his child die, which sickness?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{fɔséka} \textbf{ús=tín} in pikín dáy? | \gls FOC due.to Q=thing 3SG.POSS child die | \glt ‘Why did his child die?’

Knowledge Point: The preposition fɔséka ‘due to’ may also be employed on its own as a question word in a truncated question phrase of the type presented in \REF{ex:key:645}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fɔséka} in pikín dáy? | \gls due.to 3SG.POSS child die | \glt ‘Due to (what) did his child die?’

Knowledge Point: The third way of questioning adverbials of cause is via the idiomatic clauses wétin mék ‘\textsc{what} make’ = ‘why, how come’ and ús=tín mék \textsc{‘what} make’ \textsc{=} \textsc{‘}why, how come’ \REF{ex:key:646}. Mék also occurs with the meaning ‘(to) cause’ as a full verb in questions such as \REF{ex:key:647}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls what make 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘How come you aren’t working today?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} dá wán, ɛ́n? | \gls what make that one INTJ | \glt ‘What causes that?’

Knowledge Point: There is some variation in the degree of idiomaticity of wétin/ús=tín mék ‘what make’, which is reflected in the degree of “verbiness” of mék ‘make’. Example \REF{ex:key:646} above pres\-ents the most common way of employing wétin mék. The element mék is neither modified for a TMA category nor is it accompanied by other characteristics that would point to its status as a verb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls what make 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘How come you aren’t working today?’

Knowledge Point: In contrast, the question in \REF{ex:key:648} is indicative of a more “verby” status of mék than in \REF{ex:key:646}. Here, the questioned situation denoted by wók ‘work’ is the predicate of a quotative clause\is{quotative clauses} to the main verb mék. The quotative marker and complementiser sé ‘\textsc{quot}’ links the main and subordinate clauses:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} \textbf{sé} yu nó wók tidé? | \gls what make QUOT 2SG NEG work today | \glt ‘How come you didn’t work today?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls what make 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘How come you aren’t working today?’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:649} below contains the most verb-like instance of mék. Here, mék ‘make’ not only functions as a main verb to the complement verb wók ‘work’. It also induces a subjunctive\is{subjunctive mood} mood over the complement clause, because it is employed with its lexical meaning as a deontic causative verb (cf. \sectref{sec:9.4.4})\is{causative constructions}. Equally, the main verb mék is fully finite as can be seen by the presence of the imperfective marker de ‘\textsc{ipfv}’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=tín} \textbf{de} \textbf{mék} \textbf{sé} \textbf{mék} yu nó wók tidé? | \gls Q=thing IPFV make QUOT SBJV 2SG NEG work today | \glt ‘What is causing you not to work today?’

Knowledge Point: In Pichi, yɛ́(s) ‘yes’ is the central agreement interjection. Both yɛ́ and yɛ́s are employed in formal and informal registers alike. Compare the answer in \REF{ex:key:650b}:
Content 1: \gll Náw so, \textbf{yɛ́s}, a fít dríng=an fáyn. | \gls now like.that yes 1SG.SBJ can drink=3SG.OBJ fine | \glt ‘Now, I’m able to drink it [milk] well.’

Knowledge Point: The elements nó and nɔ́ are used as free variants in order to signal disagreement. The former element is identical in form to the general negator nó. Many Pichi speakers agree or disagree with the polarity of the question. Hence agreement with the negative polarity of the question in \REF{ex:key:651} evokes the use of the agreement marker yɛ́s:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In sentence-final position, nɔ́ functions as a question-tag, i.e. a conative interjection. In this function, nɔ́ is used in rhetorical questions as well as in biased questions, in which the speaker expresses the expectation that the answer will correspond to the polarity of the question \REF{ex:key:654}:
Content 1: \gll Yu de fíl hɔ́t \textbf{nɔ́}? | \gls 2SG IPFV feel hot INTJ | \glt ‘You’re feeling hot, aren’t you?'

Knowledge Point: Aside from that, nɔ́ also serves as a phatic interjection in order to solicit attention (cf. \sectref{sec:12.2.3}). For example, the clause in \REF{ex:key:655} underlines the speaker’s commitment to the truth of a story that he has just narrated:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nɔ́}, nó tɔ́k ɛ́n! | \gls INTJ NEG talk INTJ | \glt ‘No, don’t talk [and call into question the truth of my story].’

Knowledge Point: Strong disagreement can be expressed by the focus construction nóto só ‘\textsc{neg}.\textsc{foc} so’ = ‘that’s not how it is’. The following two sentences succeed each other in a narrative. The disagreement expressed in \REF{ex:key:656a} is underlined by sentence (b):
Content 1: \gll Dɛn tɛ́l=an sé “\textbf{nóto} só.” | \gls 3PL tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT NEG.FOC like.that | \glt ‘They said to her “that’s not how it was”.‘

Knowledge Point: Even stronger disagreement is expressed through the negative phrases nó wán dé ‘never’ \REF{ex:key:657b} and nó wé ‘no way’ \REF{ex:key:658b}. The following two sentence pairs illustrate their use in signalling disagreement in response to a question:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé}, nóto mi. | \gls NEG one day NEG.FOC 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘Never, it’s not me.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{wé}, a nó go kán. | \gls NEG way 1SG.SBJ NEG POT come | \glt ‘No way, I won’t come.’

Knowledge Point: Given the right pragmatic context, the question word\is{question words} ús=sáy ‘\textsc{where’} may signal strong disagreement as well \REF{ex:key:659b}. The imperative\is{imperatives} clause kɔmɔ́t dé ‘get lost’ can be employed to express strong and abusive disagreement \REF{ex:key:660b}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\'{U}s=sáy}? | \gls Q=side | \glt ‘Where? [not at all]’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kɔmɔ́t} \textbf{dé}! | \gls go.out there | \glt ‘Get lost!’

Knowledge Point: The answer to a content questions\is{content questions} may be given in full or truncated sentences consisting of the questioned constituent(s) as in \REF{ex:key:661b}:
Content 1: \gll Nguema Mba. | \gls NAME NAME | \glt ‘Nguema Mba’

Knowledge Point: The two successively uttered sentences \REF{ex:key:663a} and \REF{ex:key:663b} exemplify the use of sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ in signalling presentational focus{\fff}. In \REF{ex:key:663a}, the speaker provides information on the topic dán mán ‘that man’. In (b), the same speaker fills in the information gap in combination with presentational focus of the entire sentence:
Content 1: \gll Dán mán e bin kán gó na jél lɔ́n tɛ́n. | \gls that man 3SG.SBJ PST PFV go LOC jail long time | \glt ‘That man, he went to jail long ago.’
Content 2: \gll Náw e dɔ́n dáy \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls now 3SG.SBJ PRF die EMP | \glt ‘Now he is even dead.’
Content 3: \gll Dán mán e bin kán gó na jél lɔ́n tɛ́n. | \gls that man 3SG.SBJ PST PFV go LOC jail long time | \glt ‘That man, he went to jail long ago.’

Knowledge Point: The corpus contains a single occurrence of sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ preceded by a \textsc{3sg.poss} pronoun which is coreferential with the head noun of the focused NP \REF{ex:key:664}. This structure is a dislocated possessive construction{\fff} in which sɛ́f functions as a nominal in the possessed noun position. In the construction, the low-toned \textsc{3sg} possessive pronoun and sɛ́f together signal emphasis or focus of the preceding noun di bɔ́y ‘the boy’:
Content 1: \gll Wé di bɔ́y in \textbf{sɛ́f}, wé e sí mí, estaba contento. | \gls SUB DEF boy 3SG.POSS self SUB 3SG.SBJ see 1SG.INDP he.was content | \glt ‘And the boy himself, when he saw me, he was content.’

Knowledge Point: The construction in \REF{ex:key:664} is, however, marginal. Note the difference between \REF{ex:key:664} and the following \REF{ex:key:665}. In the latter example, sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ is used as a regular focus particle, postposed to the high-toned \textsc{3sg} emphatic personal pronoun:
Content 1: \gll Wé di bɔ́y in \textbf{sɛ́f}, wé e sí mí, estaba contento. | \gls SUB DEF boy 3SG.POSS self SUB 3SG.SBJ see 1SG.INDP he.was content | \glt ‘And the boy himself, when he saw me, he was content.’
Content 2: \gll Wé di bɔ́y in \textbf{sɛ́f}, wé e sí mí, estaba contento. | \gls SUB DEF boy 3SG.POSS self SUB 3SG.SBJ see 1SG.INDP he.was content | \glt ‘And the boy himself, when he saw me, he was content.’
Content 3: \gll \'{I}n \textbf{sɛ́f} gó na baf-rúm e wás. | \gls 3SG.INDP EMP go LOC bath-room 3SG.SBJ wash | \glt ‘He (by) himself went to the bathroom (and) washed.’

Knowledge Point: Contrastive use of sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ is illustrated in \REF{ex:key:666}. In its function as a focus marker, sɛ́f often assumes a reading of inclusive or exhaustive listing; hence the translation of sɛ́f as ‘too, also, even’ and ‘alone, without help’. In fact, a postposed sɛ́f most appropriately renders the notion ‘too, also’ in a sentence like \REF{ex:key:667}. {\fff}
Content 1: \gll Yu nó \textbf{sɛ́f}, yu jɔ́s kán, yu nó go sabí. | \gls 2SG know EMP 2SG just come 2SG NEG POT know | \glt ‘Even (if) you know, if you’ve just come, you won’t know.’
Content 2: \gll Mí \textbf{sɛ́f} dɔ́n rích Cotonou. | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP PRF arrive PLACE | \glt ‘I myself have been to Cotonou (too).’

Knowledge Point: The following two examples also show that sɛ́f has the most flexible scope of all particles. It may signal focus of sentences \REF{ex:key:666} as well as smaller constituents, such as a personal pronoun \REF{ex:key:667}:
Content 1: \gll Yu nó \textbf{sɛ́f}, yu jɔ́s kán, yu nó go sabí. | \gls 2SG know EMP 2SG just come 2SG NEG POT know | \glt ‘Even (if) you know, if you’ve just come, you won’t know.’
Content 2: \gll Mí \textbf{sɛ́f} dɔ́n rích Cotonou. | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP PRF arrive PLACE | \glt ‘I myself have been to Cotonou (too).’

Knowledge Point: The particle sénwe ‘\textsc{emp}’ is presumably a lexicalised collocation (i.e. sén.wé ‘same.way’). It is employed in the same way as sɛ́f in order to signal presentational and contrastive focus{\fff} \REF{ex:key:668}. The use of sénwe as a clausal focus particle is not attested. In general, sénwe occurs less frequently than sɛ́f and is found more often to focus personal pronouns than full nouns. Consider the following example, in which sénwe signals presentational focus of the personal pronoun yú ‘\textsc{2sg.indp}’:
Content 1: \gll Dí wán, \textbf{yú} \textbf{sénwe} yu de gó. | \gls this one 2SG.INDP EMP 2SG IPFV go | \glt ‘This time, you yourself are going [to die].’

Knowledge Point: The element ó ‘\textsc{intj}’ may signal presentational or contrastive focus of entire clauses as in \REF{ex:key:670} below. The particle is a sentence-final element which has scope over all preceding material, which may be a predicate-less sentence \REF{ex:key:669} or a clause \REF{ex:key:670}. However, modification by means of ó also colours the sentence with meanings like warning, assertion, empathy, or emphasis (cf. \sectref{sec:12.2.4} for more details):
Content 1: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} bin dɔ́n, a bin dɔ́n blánt fɔ Gabón \textbf{ó}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST PRF 1SG.SBJ PST PRF reside PREP Gabon SP | \glt ‘I’ve already, I’ve already lived in Gabon [contrary to what you think].’
Content 2: \gll Bata tɔ́ng \textbf{ó}. | \gls PLACE tongue SP | \glt ‘That’s the Fang language for you [see how peculiar it is].’
Content 3: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} bin dɔ́n, a bin dɔ́n blánt fɔ Gabón \textbf{ó}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST PRF 1SG.SBJ PST PRF reside PREP Gabon SP | \glt ‘I’ve already, I’ve already lived in Gabon [contrary to what you think].’

Knowledge Point: The interjection ɛ́n ‘\textsc{intj}’ is principally employed in sentence-final position as a chan\-nel-checking device in order to solicit the attention of an addressee (cf. also \sectref{sec:12.2.2}). Channel-checking automatically lends prominence to a preceding utterance, hence ɛ́n may function very much like other sentential focus particles \REF{ex:key:671}.
Content 1: \gll Djunais, yu badhát \textbf{ɛ́n}. | \gls NAME 2SG be.mean INTJ | \glt ‘Djunais you‘re really mean.’

Knowledge Point: Beyond that, ɛ́n may also occur in mid-sentence followed by a pause, in order to focus a single constituent. In \REF{ex:key:672}, the \ili{Spanish} depictive adjective fresco ‘fresh’ is fronted and singled out for focus by ɛ́n:
Content 1: \gll Fresco \textbf{ɛ́n}, dɛn de gí wí. | \gls fresh INTJ 3PL IPFV give 1PL.INDP | \glt ‘Fresh, (that’s how) they would give (it) to us.’

Knowledge Point: Any sentence constituent may be subjected to particle focus save dependent personal pronouns, determiners, and \textsc{TMA} particles. Equally, the individual elements of multi-constituent \textsc{NPs} cannot be focused, since an \textsc{NP} must be focused in its entirety. Other than that, constituents of varying degrees of complexity may be focused. Sentence \REF{ex:key:673} features a prepositional phrase with a single noun under focus, and \REF{ex:key:674} the complex prepositional phrase and reflexive construction na yu skín ‘on you(r body)’:
Content 1: \gll Na Trinidad \textbf{sɛ́f} nɔ́? | \gls LOC PLACE EMP INTJ | \glt ‘Even in Trinidad, right?’
Content 2: \gll Ɛf e de gó yu se supone que e de fáyn na yu skin \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls if 3SG.SBJ IPFV go 2SG REFL assume that 3SG.SBJ IPFV fine LOC 2SG body EMP | \glt ‘If it goes well with you, it’s assumed that it looks nice on you(r body).’

Knowledge Point: In dialogue, verbless, prosodically independent sentences can be found which consist of a focused constituent alone. By singling out particular elements in such a way, a speaker may convey strong emphatic force. Compare the discourse excerpt in the two following examples. In \REF{ex:key:675a} speaker (hi) emphasises the lack of responsibility of certain mothers by utilising focus with sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’. Her statement is confirmed by speaker (bo) in (b):
Content 1: \gll Bɔt dán káyn mamá dɛn \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls but that kind mother PL EMP | \glt ‘But these kinds of mother, really.’

Knowledge Point: The corpus contains many examples of focused adverbial phrases, in particular time adverbials, such as tumɔ́ro ‘tomorrow’ in \REF{ex:key:676}:
Content 1: \gll Wé a dɔ́n jɔ́ch dɛ́n, a sé “\textbf{tumɔ́ro} \textbf{sénwe} a de gó mít in mán”. | \gls SUB 1SG.SBJ PRF judge 3PL.INDP 1SG.SBJ QUOT tomorrow EMP 1SG.SBJ IPFV go meet 3SG.POSS man | \glt ‘When I had talked them down, I said “tomorrow, I’m going to meet her husband”.’

Knowledge Point: Subordinate clauses may be focused by the same means as other, smaller sentence constituents. The relative clause{\fff} in \REF{ex:key:677} is under the scope of the particle sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’. In \REF{ex:key:678}, the clause introduced by sé ‘\textsc{quot}’ is under focus by means of the sentence-final particle ó:
Content 1: \gll E lúk di análisis, tiene paludismo de una cruz \textbf{wé} kin kíl pikín \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ look DEF analysis he.has malaria of one cross SUB HAB kill child EMP | \glt ‘She [the doctor] looked at the analysis “he has malaria of one cross which even kills children”.’
Content 2: \gll Bikɔs dɛn tɔ́k \textbf{sé} na paludismo \textbf{ó}. | \gls because 3PL talk QUOT FOC malaria SP | \glt ‘Because they said that it’s malaria.’

Knowledge Point: Elements which are part of a coordinate structure can be focused separately \REF{ex:key:679}, and there is no restriction save intelligibility on the number of elements that can be focused in one sentence. Compare \REF{ex:key:679} which features constituent focus by means of the particle sɛ́f and clausal focus by means of a sentence-final ó:
Content 1: \gll Tú pípul \textbf{sɛ́f} wet wán pikín dɔ́n kán \textbf{ó}. | \gls two people EMP with one child PRF come SP | \glt ‘Even two people and one child have come.’
Content 2: \gll Tú pípul \textbf{sɛ́f} wet wán pikín dɔ́n kán \textbf{ó}. | \gls two people EMP with one child PRF come SP | \glt ‘Even two people and one child have come.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:680} presents clausal focus (or alternatively focus of the object NP dán ‘convence’ dé) through sɛ́f, as well as focus of the ensuing adverbial phrase na Pichi by means of sénwe:
Content 1: \gll A bin wánt tɔ́k dán “convence” dé sɛ́f na Pichi \textbf{sénwe}, a nó de mɛ́mba. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST want talk that convince there EMP LOC Pichi EMP 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV remember | \glt ‘I had actually wanted to say that “convence” there in Pichi itself (but) I don’t remember [how to say it].’

Knowledge Point: Personal pronouns can be focused through the use of the corresponding emphatic, independent form alone instead of resorting to sɛ́f or sénwe (cf. \ref{ex:key:667}–\ref{ex:key:668} above). Compare subject focus in the rhetorical question in \REF{ex:key:682}:
Content 1: \gll Mí \textbf{sɛ́f} dɔ́n rích Cotonou. | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP PRF arrive PLACE | \glt ‘I myself have been to Cotonou (too).’
Content 2: \gll Dí wán, \textbf{yú} \textbf{sénwe} yu de gó. | \gls this one 2SG.INDP EMP 2SG IPFV go | \glt ‘This time, you yourself are going [to die].’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mí} wánt dán mán? | \gls 1SG.INDP want that man | \glt ‘Do I [EMP] want that man?’

Knowledge Point: Focused constituents may appear in situ, i.e. in the same syntactic position assigned to them in focus-neutral clauses. When this is the case, focus is signalled by the presence of a particle. In \REF{ex:key:683}, the subject NP in papá ‘her father’ is highlighted via presentational focus{\fff} only by means of the post-posed emphatic particle sɛ́f:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta in \textbf{papá} \textbf{sɛ́f} kán ték=an. | \gls then 3SG.POSS father EMP come take=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘Then her father came to take her.’

Knowledge Point: Focused non-subject \textsc{NPs} may also be found in situ together with a focus particle. Compare the focused PP fɔ di pikín in \REF{ex:key:684}:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta e nóto, e nó fáyn fɔ di pikín \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls then 3SG.SBJ NEG.FOC 3SG.SBJ NEG fine PREP DEF child EMP | \glt ‘Then it’s not, it’s not good for the child itself.’

Knowledge Point: When an object NP retains its usual syntactic position after the verb and is followed by a focus particle, discourse context and the presence of suprasegmental focus will usually disambiguate the resulting structure as involving clausal or phrasal focus. In \REF{ex:key:685} the particle sɛ́f ‘self, \textsc{emp}’ may be construed as having narrow scope over the object NP dán torí ‘that story’, or alternatively, broad scope over the entire sentence:
Content 1: \gll Mí nó sabí us mán dɛn kíl, a nɔ́ba hía dán torí \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls 1SG.INDP NEG know which man 3PL kill 1SG.SBJ NEG.PRF hear that story EMP | \glt ‘I don’t know who was killed, I haven’t even heard that story yet.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbials may be be focused by exploiting their syntactic flexibility and placing them at the head of the sentence in combination with a focus particle \REF{ex:key:686}. The corpus contains no instance of an object that has been fronted for focus. We only find focused, sentence-initial non-subjects occuring in cleft constructions (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:702}):
Content 1: \gll Lagos \textbf{sɛ́f}, e gɛ́t di sáy wé na di húman dɛn de máred di mán. | \gls PLACE EMP 3SG.SBJ get DEF side SUB FOC DEF woman PL IPFV marry DEF man | \glt ‘Even in Lagos, there is a place where it’s the women (who) marry the men.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{wán} \textbf{smɔ́l} \textbf{híl} e klém. | \gls FOC one small hill 3SG.SBJ climb | \glt ‘It’s a small hill that he climbed.’

Knowledge Point: For example, sentence \REF{ex:key:687} features the dislocated and topical object NP di róp ‘the rope’, followed by the focus particle sɛ́f. In contrast to fronting (i.e. in question formation), the use of dislocation{\fff} comes along with the use of a resumptive pronoun{\fff} (here the \textsc{3sg.obj} pronoun =an) in the original object position of the left-dislocated constituent:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta di róp \textbf{sɛ́f}, wi nó sí nó mán wé e híb=\textbf{an}. | \gls then DEF rope EMP 1PL NEG see NEG man SUB 3SG.SBJ throw=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘And the rope, we didn’t see anybody who threw it.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:688} contains a left-dislocated object NP, the emphatic pronoun mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’, which is reiterated by the coreferential object pronoun mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’. In this example, too, focus of the dislocated topic is overtly signalled by means of the particle sɛ́f:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mi} \textbf{sɛ́f}, ɔ́l pɔ́sin dɛn kin áks mi sé ‘yu dɔ́n bɔ́n?’ | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP all person 3PL HAB ask 1SG.INDP QUOT 2SG PRF give.birth | \glt ‘Even me, everybody asks me “have you given birth [do you have a child]?”'

Knowledge Point: Constructions involving personal pronouns are as well the only ones in which “afterthought” apposition is frequently employed in order to signal focus of personal pronouns. Example \REF{ex:key:689} contains an appositive mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp’} within the scope of the focus particle sénwe and coreferential with the preceding dependent personal pronoun a ‘\textsc{1sg.sbj’}:
Content 1: \gll A go wás=an wet mi hán \textbf{mí} \textbf{sénwe}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ POT wash=3SG.OBJ with 1SG.POSS hand 1SG.INDP EMP | \glt ‘I myself would wash it with my hand.’

Knowledge Point: The negative focus marker nóto is employed instead of na to signal negative, contrastive focus. In example \REF{ex:key:691}, nóto signals contrastive focus of the object pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’. Note the use of the emphatic form of the personal pronoun as well as the occurrence of a resumptive =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ at the end of the clause:
Content 1: \gll Sé pero mán mi brɔ́da dát, ús=tín e de dú na yá, \textbf{nóto} \textbf{ín} wi bɛ́r=\textbf{an}? | \gls QUOT but man 1SG.POSS brother that Q=thing 3SG.SBJ IPFV do LOC here NEG.FOC 3SG.INDP 1PL bury=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘But man, that’s my brother, what’s he doing here, isn’t it him that we buried?’

Knowledge Point: The \ili{Spanish}-origin focusing device es que ‘it is that’ is regularly employed to signal presentational focus with clauses and sentences \REF{ex:key:692}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Es} \textbf{que} e fáyn wé yu nó sabí sé e kɔmɔ́t fɔ di animal. | \gls it.is that 3SG.SBJ fine SUB 2SG NEG know QUOT 3SG.SBJ come.out PREP DEF animal | \glt ‘It’s that it is fine when you don’t know that it [the milk] has just come out of the animal.’

Knowledge Point: Cleft constructions may be employed for signalling presentational and contrastive focus alike. In the following three sentences, speaker (ma) talks about a dog that has been tied to a tree by the neighbours downstairs. After providing circumstantial information in (\ref{ex:key:693a}–b), new information is introduced by presentational focus in (c):
Content 1: \gll Dɛn táy=an. | \gls 3PL tie=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘They’ve tied it [that’s why it’s barking].’

Knowledge Point: The use of contrastive\is{contrastive focus} focus is exemplified in the discourse excerpt below. In \REF{ex:key:694a}, speaker (dj) jokingly denies any involvement in the spell that has been cast on speaker (dj). Speaker (ru) retorts by contrastively focusing the \textsc{2sg} pronoun used in addressing his interlocutor in (b):
Content 1: \gll Nó mete mí ínsay dí tɔ́k a bɛ́g! | \gls NEG put 1SG.INDP inside this talk 1SG.SBJ ask.for | \glt ‘Don’t involve me in this matter, please!’

Knowledge Point: Both na ‘\textsc{foc}’ and nóto ‘\textsc{neg}.\textsc{foc}’ also function as copula-like elements in clauses like \REF{ex:key:695b}, in which a concrete entity is identified in discourse (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.1} for an extensive treatment of the copula functions of na/nóto). Likewise, na/nóto occur as identity copulas in equative constructions like \REF{ex:key:696}, where we find nominal constituents on both sides of the copula:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Di húman \textbf{na} strɔ́n húman. | \gls DEF woman FOC strong woman | \glt ‘The woman is a strong woman.’

Knowledge Point: Presumably, the identificational function of na/nóto in pragmatic contexts like \REF{ex:key:695b} is the point of departure for the focus-marking and identity (i.e. equative) functions of na/nóto (\citealt[96]{HeineKuteva2002}). The difference between copula clauses and cleft focus has a structural correlate. In focus constructions, the out-of-focus part of the sentence is not normally expressed as a relative clause\is{relative clauses}. Compare the pragmatically neutral clause in \REF{ex:key:697a} and the corresponding focus construction (b), in which the relativiser wé is absent (indicated by {\emptyset}):
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Dɛn sɛ́n di bɔ́l. | \gls 3PL send DEF ball | \glt ‘The ball was thrown.’

Knowledge Point: In copula clauses, however, the use of an overt relative clause introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’ is obligatory if the identified entity is to be modified by a clause. In \REF{ex:key:698a}, new information is introduced. This given information is implicitly referred to by sentence (b), which is therefore best seen to constitute an equative clause rather than a focus construction:
Content 1: \gll Háw yu kin kɔ́l=an wé pɔ́sin de siente vergüenza? | \gls how 2SG HAB call=3SG.OBJ SUB person IPFV feel shame | \glt ‘How do you call it, when a person feels ashamed?’

Knowledge Point: By comparison, the insertion of a \textsc{3sg} peronal pronoun is ungrammatical in the focus construction in \REF{ex:key:700}, since na/nóto is non-referential in these constructions. Likewise, a cleft focus construction cannot be rephrased as a presentative clause (cf. \sectref{sec:7.4.4}):
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Cleft-focused non-subjects appear at the beginning of the sentence \REF{ex:key:702}. The use of resumptive pronoun\is{resumptive pronouns}s is not attested and the expression of the out-of-focus part of the sentence as a relative clause like in \REF{ex:key:703} is rare:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{wán} \textbf{smɔ́l} \textbf{híl} e klém. | \gls FOC one small hill 3SG.SBJ climb | \glt ‘It’s a small hill that he climbed.’
Content 2: \gll Wé wi smɔ́l, \textbf{na} \textbf{sósó} \textbf{Píchi} wé wi de tɔ́k. | \gls SUB 1PL be.small FOC only Pichi SUB 1PL IPFV talk | \glt ‘When we were small, it’s only Pichi that we would talk.’

Knowledge Point: There are also numerous instances of focused adverbs. Compare the adverb só ‘so, like this’ in \REF{ex:key:704}, which is often encountered in a cleft construction na só ‘it’s like that, that’s how it is’, as well as focused dé ‘there’ \REF{ex:key:705}:
Content 1: \gll Sí, \textbf{na} \textbf{só} mí sɛ́f kin dé. | \gls see FOC like.that 1SG.INDP EMP HAB BE.LOC | \glt ‘See, it’s like that that I’m also usually like.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{dé} e de gó, yu nó dé? | \gls FOC there 3SG.SBJ IPFV go 2SG know there | \glt ‘It’s there that she’s going, you know there [that place]?’

Knowledge Point: The following two examples are of interest because they each present a focus-neutral clause and constituent focus in one sentence. In \REF{ex:key:706}, the manner adverbial rɔn-sáy ‘backwards’ is first encountered in the clause-final adverbial position, then fronted for presentational focus in a na{}-focus construction. The same applies to fá ‘be far’, which is employed as a locative adverbial\is{locative adverbials} in \REF{ex:key:707}:
Content 1: \gll E de wáka rɔn-sáy, \textbf{na} \textbf{rɔn-sáy} e wáka. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV walk wrong-side FOC wrong.CPD-side 3SG.SBJ walk | \glt ‘He is walking backwards, it’s backwards that he walked.’
Content 2: \gll E sé e kɔmɔ́t fá, \textbf{na} \textbf{fá} e kɔmɔ́t. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT 3SG.SBJ come.out far FOC far 3SG.SBJ come.out | \glt ‘He said he came from far away, it’s far away that he was from.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:708} contains an instrumental prepostional phrase featuring the preposition wet ‘with’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{wet} \textbf{ús=tín} dɛn bíl=an? | \gls FOC with Q=thing 3PL build=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘It’s with what that it was built?’

Knowledge Point: Sequences of the homophones na ‘\textsc{foc}’ and na ‘\textsc{loc}’ are not attested. Hence, the use of a focused locative prepositional phrase featuring fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ as a locative\is{general locative preposition} preposition serves as an alternative in \REF{ex:key:709}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{dán} \textbf{área} wi sté. | \gls FOC PREP that area 1PL stay | \glt ‘It’s in that area that we stay.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:710}, we witness the use of na sé ‘it is that’ in order to focus a sentence containing the verb wánt ‘want’ together with its subjunctive\is{subjunctive mood} complements. Besides cleft focus, this sentence exemplifies other features that characterise emphatic speech in Pichi: The TMA marker sequence dɔ́n de ‘\textsc{prf} \textsc{ipfv’} is employed instead of de \textsc{‘ipfv’} alone, and the repetitive use of verbs with similar meanings serves as a means of emphatic reinforcement:
Content 1: \gll Wé yu dɔ́n de nák, \textbf{na} \textbf{sé} yu wánt sɔn tín e \textbf{brók}, \textbf{mék} e krás, \textbf{mék} e \textbf{destroza}. | \gls SUB 2SG PRF IPFV hit FOC QUOT 2SG want some thing 3SG.SBJ break SBJV 3SG.SBJ crash SBJV 3SG.SBJ destroy | \glt ‘When you’re hitting, it’s that you want a thing to break, to crash, to be destroyed.’

Knowledge Point: Nóto sé ‘it’s not that’ always signals contrastive focus of a clause or sentence \REF{ex:key:711}. In \REF{ex:key:712}, a conditional clause is singled out for focus. Hence, the negative focus marker nóto appears after ɛf ‘if’:
Content 1: \gll E de kráy pero \textbf{nóto} \textbf{sé} e wánt chɔ́p. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV cry but NEG.FOC QUOT 3SG.SBJ want eat | \glt ‘He is crying but it’s not the he wants to eat.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ɛf} \textbf{nóto} yu báy dán húman go bít yú sóté yu go gó lɛ́f=an. | \gls if NEG.FOC 2SG buy that woman POT beat 2SG.INDP until 2SG POT go leave=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘If it’s not that [the correct type] you’ve bought, that woman would beat you until you would go return it.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:714}, the topical \textsc{NP} dí káyn pikín ‘this kind of child’ is set off from the rest of the sentence by continuative intonation\is{continuative intonation} and a pause. The subsequent clause is under presentational focus with es que ‘it’s that’, and the topical \textsc{NP} is picked up by the resumptive pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’:
Content 1: \gll Entonces \textbf{dí} \textbf{káyn} \textbf{pikín}, \textbf{es} \textbf{que} normalmente e go tɛ́l yú dán tín, (...) | \gls so this kind child it.is that normally 3SG.SBJ POT tell 2SG.INDP that thing (...) | \glt So this kind of child, it’s that usually it will tell you exactly that (...)’

Knowledge Point: Cleft focus is characterised by a large degree of syntactic flexibility. For example, focusing into a relative clause\is{relative clauses} is permitted. Example \REF{ex:key:716} presents a subject relative clause featuring focus of a \textsc{3sg} person (i.e. na ín ‘it’s him’), anaphoric to the preceding head nominal wán ‘one (person)’:
Content 1: \gll Bɛt e fíba sé \textbf{wán} dé wé \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} de púl di ɔ́da wán di torí. | \gls but 3SG.SBJ resemble QUOT one BE.LOC SUB FOC 3SG.INDP IPFV pull DEF other one DEF story | \glt ‘But it seems that one is there that it’s him who is telling the other one a story.’

Knowledge Point: Cleft constructions of the type in \REF{ex:key:716} above, where a resumptive element is focused, serve an important function in discourse{\fff}. They serve as anaphors that establish reference to preceding topical material in the sentence or the paragraph. The relevant collocations involve the focus particle na ‘\textsc{foc}’ followed by the adverbs yá ‘here’, dé ‘there’, só ‘so, like that’, the personal pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’, as well as complex NPs like dán tɛ́n ‘that time’ and di tín ‘the thing’. Mostly, these collocations function as resumptive adverbials of location, time, or cause, but ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’ may also refer to preceding subjects and objects{\fff}.
Content 1: \gll Bɛt e fíba sé \textbf{wán} dé wé \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} de púl di ɔ́da wán di torí. | \gls but 3SG.SBJ resemble QUOT one BE.LOC SUB FOC 3SG.INDP IPFV pull DEF other one DEF story | \glt ‘But it seems that one is there that it’s him who is telling the other one a story.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:717}, the topical, clefted adverbial phrase frɔn in hós ‘from her house’ is anaphorically referred to by another clefted adverbial, namely dé ‘there’:
Content 1: \gll Na frɔn in hós, \textbf{na} \textbf{dé} yu go ték máred. | \gls FOC from 3SG.POSS house FOC there 2SG POT take marry | \glt ‘It’s from her house, it’s there that you’d enter marriage.’

Knowledge Point: A similar anaphoric relation holds between di sáy ‘the place’ and na dé ‘it’s there’ in \REF{ex:key:718}. In fact, the deictic locative adverbs\is{locative adverbials} dé ‘there’ and yá ‘here’, as well as the deictic manner adverbial só ‘like that’ need to be clefted in this way, if they are to appear in the clause-initial, rather than their usual clause-final position:
Content 1: \gll Di sáy wé mɔní dé, \textbf{na} \textbf{dé} yu gɛ́fɔ gó. | \gls DEF side SUB money BE.LOC FOC there 2SG have.to go | \glt ‘The place where there’s money, that’s where you have to go.’

Knowledge Point: An anaphoric temporal relation may also be established by means of the locative adverbs yá ‘here’ and dé ‘there’. In \REF{ex:key:719}, the left-dislocated and topical \ili{Spanish} adverbial a los quince años completamente is picked up by the resumptive focus construction na yá ‘\textsc{foc} here’ = ‘that’s when’. The same principle is at work in \REF{ex:key:720}, where na dé refers to a preceding time clause earlier in the paragraph:
Content 1: \gll A los quince años, \textbf{na} \textbf{yá} e kán. | \gls at DEF.PL fifteen years FOC here 3SG.SBJ come | \glt ‘With exactly fifteen years, that’s when she came.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{dé} dán, dán kandá, dán tín, dán membrano, na dé e kɔmɔ́t. | \gls FOC there that that skin that thing that membrane FOC there 3SG.SBJ go.out | \glt ‘That’s when that, that skin, that thing, that membrane, that’s when it came out.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:721}, na ín refers to the antecedent subject under focus na di fáyn chɔ́p ‘it’s the good food’. Example \REF{ex:key:722} features a resumptive na ín anaphorical to the dislocated, topical object dís traje fɔ mono ‘this overall-like suit’:
Content 1: \gll Na di fáyn chɔ́p, \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} de stáwt=an. | \gls FOC DEF fine food FOC 3SG.INDP IPFV make.corpulent=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘It’s the good food, that’s what’s making her corpulent.’
Content 2: \gll Tɛ́l=an sé, nɔ́, dís traje fɔ mono, \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} e wánt. | \gls tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT INTJ this suit PREP overall FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ want | \glt ‘(He) told him, no, this overall-like suit, that’s what he wants.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:723}, na ín refers to an antecedent time clause introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’. When there is a relation of temporal succession like in this example, it is only natural that the wé{}-clause precedes the main clause:
Content 1: \gll Wé e dɔ́n dé pan di chía, \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} e strét. | \gls SUB 3SG.SBJ PRF BE.LOC on DEF chair FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ be.straight | \glt ‘When she was completely on the chair, that’s when she straightened up.’

Knowledge Point: Whenever this the case, the phrasal expressions na ín (mék) ‘\textsc{foc} \textsc{3sg.indp} (make)’ = ‘that’s why’ \REF{ex:key:724} or alternatively, na di tín (mék) ‘\textsc{foc} \textsc{def} thing (make)’ = ‘that’s why’ \REF{ex:key:725} may refer anaphorically to the preceding cause clause (cf. \ref{ex:key:646} for the analoguous content question):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{bikɔs} in abuelo dɔ́n dáy, \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} e de kráy. | \gls FOC because 3SG.POSS grandfather PRF die FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV cry | \glt ‘It’s because his grandfather has died, that’s why he’s crying like that.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{bikɔs} dɛn púl di motó, \textbf{na} \textbf{di} \textbf{tín} \textbf{mék} e chakrá. | \gls FOC because 3PL remove DEF car FOC DEF thing make 3SG.SBJ destroy | \glt ‘It’s because the car was removed, that’s why it got broken.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Wétin} \textbf{mék} yu nó de wók tidé? | \gls what make 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘How come you aren’t working today?’

Knowledge Point: Amongst the sentences involving focus of resumptive elements presented so far, we also find focused constituents appearing in the initial position which are not preceded by the focus marker na (eg. \ref{ex:key:719} and \ref{ex:key:722}). There is no reason to see these structures as being fundamentally different from cleft constructions involving the focus marker na. The only thing “missing” in these constructions is the focus particle.
Content 1: \gll A los quince años, \textbf{na} \textbf{yá} e kán. | \gls at DEF.PL fifteen years FOC here 3SG.SBJ come | \glt ‘With exactly fifteen years, that’s when she came.’
Content 2: \gll Tɛ́l=an sé, nɔ́, dís traje fɔ mono, \textbf{na} \textbf{ín} e wánt. | \gls tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT INTJ this suit PREP overall FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ want | \glt ‘(He) told him, no, this overall-like suit, that’s what he wants.’

Knowledge Point: Pichi features a presentative construction involving na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto as well as the proximal and distal demonstrative forms dís ‘this’ \REF{ex:key:726} and dat ‘that’ \REF{ex:key:727} in sentence-final position. Presentatives may be seen as inverted copula clauses with particular deictic force, which direct an addressee’s attention to, and identify, an entity. By highlighting an entity in this way, presentatives manifest a functional overlap with (presentational) cleft constructions: \is{cleft constructions}
