Content 1: \gll E sé \textbf{na} mán \textbf{dís}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT FOC man this | \glt ‘He said “this is a man”.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} róp \textbf{dát}. | \gls FOC rope that | \glt ‘That’s a rope.’

Knowledge Point: Examples (\ref{ex:key:726}–\ref{ex:key:727}) may also be expressed with less deictic force as regular copula clauses. The following two equative clauses feature the demonstratives dí ‘this’ and dán ‘that’ in the ordinary prenominal position. When employed in an NP in this way, demonstratives may be realised as the short forms dí and dá respectively. However, these apocopated forms do not occur in sentence-final position in presentatives like (\ref{ex:key:726}–\ref{ex:key:727}) above:
Content 1: \gll E sé \textbf{na} mán \textbf{dís}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT FOC man this | \glt ‘He said “this is a man”.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} róp \textbf{dát}. | \gls FOC rope that | \glt ‘That’s a rope.’
Content 3: \gll E sé \textbf{na} mán \textbf{dís}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT FOC man this | \glt ‘He said “this is a man”.’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Na} róp \textbf{dát}. | \gls FOC rope that | \glt ‘That’s a rope.’

Knowledge Point: The highlighted NP of a presentative construction may be modified by further constituents in the same way as a nominal participant in an equative clause. In \REF{ex:key:730}, the NP chɔ́p ‘food’ has been modified prenominally by bɛ́ta ‘very good’ and post-nominally by a relative clause{\fff} introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} di bɛ́ta chɔ́p \textbf{wé} mán de chɔ́p dát. | \gls FOC DEF very.good food SUB man IPFV food that | \glt ‘That was the best food that one [I] was eating.’

Knowledge Point: Content questions\is{content questions} may also be formulated as presentatives \REF{ex:key:731}, in which case they may occur without a preposed na. This distribution may be linked to the fact that questioned constituents are focused by default, and may optionally co-occur with na{}-focus anyway (cf. \sectref{sec:7.3.2}):
Content 1: \gll Sé papá gɔ́d \textbf{ús}=\textbf{káyn} trɔ́bul \textbf{dís}? | \gls QUOT father God Q=kind trouble this | \glt ‘(I) said God, what (kind of) trouble (is) this?’

Knowledge Point: The predicate cleft construction in \REF{ex:key:733} features a stative verb, the property item bíg ‘be big’. Like other cleft constructions, predicate cleft does not require marking of the out-of-focus part of the sentence as a relative clause\is{relative clauses}. This is, in fact rejected in unison by all speakers who were asked about this possibility \REF{ex:key:734}:
Content 1: \gll Chico, \textbf{na} \textbf{bíg} e \textbf{bíg}. | \gls boy FOC big 3SG.SBJ big | \glt ‘Oh boy, it’s really big.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Sometimes verbs are clefted together with a pronominal object \REF{ex:key:735}. If this is the case, the pronominal object is not repeated with the second verb. The fronting\is{fronting} of a subject or adverbial modifier together with the verb is not accepted \REF{ex:key:736}:
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{krách}=an yu de \textbf{skrách}. | \gls FOC scratch=3SG.OBJ 2SG IPFV scratch | \glt ‘You’re actually scratching it.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: However, verbs are not clefted together with TMA markers \REF{ex:key:737}. These always remain in their “original” position with the second verb. The two following examples are of interest because they involve clefting of the major verb of a motion-direction SVC. As these examples show, the minor verb gó ‘go’ remains in its original syntactic position \REF{ex:key:738}: \is{motion verbs}
Content 1: \gll Na wáka wi \textbf{bin} \textbf{de} wáka \textbf{gó} dé. | \gls FOC walk 1PL PST IPFV walk go there | \glt ‘We actually walked there.’
Content 2: \gll Na wáka wi \textbf{wáka} \textbf{gó} dé. | \gls FOC walk 1PL walk go there | \glt ‘We walked there.’

Knowledge Point: The same holds for complements of auxiliaries. In \REF{ex:key:739}, it is once again only the major verb wáka ‘walk’ that gets fronted, while the modal auxiliary verb wánt ‘want’ stays behind:
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{wáka} e \textbf{wánt} \textbf{wáka} só. | \gls FOC walk 3SG.SBJ want walk like.this | \glt ‘He really wants to walk right now.’

Knowledge Point: A few Pichi verbs have homophonous nominal counterparts which are not merely action nominalisations. One of these is chɔ́p, which means ‘eat’ as a verb and ‘food’ (rather than only ‘eating’) as a noun. While \REF{ex:key:740} may be interpreted as involving either predicate or nominal cleft, the cleft construction in \REF{ex:key:741} is unlikely to be anything else than a nominal cleft construction, since the focused noun chɔ́p ‘food’ is modified by bɔkú ‘be much’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{chɔ́p} e \textbf{chɔ́p} yɛ́stadé ó. | \gls FOC eat/food 3SG.SBJ eat yesterday SP | \glt ‘He really ate yesterday.’ or ‘It’s (really good) food that he ate yesterday.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{chɔ́p} e kin \textbf{chɔ́p}. | \gls FOC much food 3SG.SBJ HAB eat | \glt ‘It’s a hell of a lot of food that he usually eats.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:742}, NP focus (i.e. dís wán sɛ́f ‘this one \textsc{emp}’ co-occurs with a predicate featuring the perfect marker dɔ́n and the imperfective marker de. Sentence \REF{ex:key:743} additionally features the completive aspect{\fff} auxiliary verb fínis ‘finish (doing something)’, which adds even more emphatic force:
Content 1: \gll Dís wán \textbf{sɛ́f}, yu \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{de} tráy. | \gls this one EMP 2SG PRF IPFV try | \glt ‘Even this [little Bube that you speak], you’re really making an effort.’
Content 2: \gll Náw a \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{de} \textbf{fínis} sém fɔ wɛ́r dán sús. | \gls now 1SG.SBJ PRF IPFV finish be.ashamed PREP wear that shoe | \glt ‘Now I’m really ashamed to be wearing that (pair of) shoes.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbial modification, for example via the value property items fáyn ‘be fine’ and bád ‘be bad’ or the quantity property item bɔkú ‘be much’ \REF{ex:key:744}, may also express emphasis by itself or in conjunction with other elements and/or focus constructions. The use of the demonstrative determiner dán ‘that’ together with the possessive construction\is{possessive constructions} in yáy ‘his eye’ builds up additional emphatic force in \REF{ex:key:744}:
Content 1: \gll E de para na dán in yáy \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{bád.} | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV stand LOC that 3SG.POSS eye much bad | \glt ‘It [the white spot in his eye] just sits there in that his eye really bad.’
Content 2: \gll E de para na dán in yáy \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{bád.} | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV stand LOC that 3SG.POSS eye much bad | \glt ‘It [the white spot in his eye] just sits there in that his eye really bad.’

Knowledge Point: Other means of expressing emphasis and by extension various nuances of sentential focus are the segmental and suprasegmental means outlined in \sectref{sec:3.2.5}, \sectref{sec:3.4.2} and \sectref{sec:7.7.3}, the various forms of iteration, i.e. repetition\is{repetition} \REF{ex:key:745} and reduplication, predicate cleft, and cognate objects \is{cognate objects}– the latter in combination with the particle ó in \REF{ex:key:746} as well as ideophones\is{ideophones} \REF{ex:key:747}:
Content 1: \gll Ɛ́n, bɔt ín sidɔ́n \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{dɔ́n} yandá. | \gls yes but 3SG.INDP stay down REP REP yonder | \glt ‘Yes, but he stays far down there.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn bin \textbf{fáyn} wán \textbf{fáyn} \textbf{ó}. | \gls 3PL PST fine one fine SP | \glt ‘They were really beautiful.’
Content 3: \gll Dɛn nák=an na in chɛ́s \textbf{kip}. | \gls 3PL hit=3SG.OBJ LOC 3SG.POSS chest IDEO | \glt ‘They hit him (hard) in the chest with a thumping sound.’

Knowledge Point: There is a strong tendency for definite subject \textsc{NPs} to be marked as topical by an intonation break, i.e. a short pause and/or continuative intonation\is{continuative intonation}, and a resumptive subject pronoun (cf. also \sectref{sec:7.1.1}). The definite subject in \REF{ex:key:748} is set off from the rest of the clause by an intonation break, indicated by a comma. At the same time, the following coreferential resumptive pronoun\is{resumptive pronouns} e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ reiterates the topical subject \textsc{NP} dán skúl ‘that school’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dán} \textbf{skúl}, \textbf{e} dé nía bɛrin-grɔ́n, nɔ́? | \gls that school 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC near burial.CPD-ground INTJ | \glt ‘That school is near the cemetery, right?’

Knowledge Point: In contrast, the data does not contain a single instance of a resumptive subject pronoun in a clause featuring an indefinite subject. Such clauses are formed in the way of \REF{ex:key:749} without a resumptive pronoun:
Content 1: \gll Wán dé wán pikín bin de sík. | \gls one day one child PST IPFV sick | \glt ‘One day, a child was sick.’

Knowledge Point: Non-subject topical \textsc{NPs} also appear at the beginning of the sentence, are normally separated from the rest of the clause by an intonation break, and are referred to by a resumptive element in the clause. The dislocated object di cartón ‘the carton’ in \REF{ex:key:750} is resumed by the coreferential object pronoun àn ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dí} \textbf{cartón}, \textbf{e} mít=an yá? | \gls this carton 3SG.SBJ meet=3SG.OBJ here | \glt ‘This cardboard box, did she find it here?’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:751}, the topical object NP ɛ́ni tín ‘everything’ is reiterated by the resumptive, coreferential object prounoun =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ after the verb púl ‘remove’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ɛ́ni} \textbf{tín}, yu wɔ́nt púl=\textbf{an} na puerto yu de pé. | \gls every thing 2SG want remove=3SG.OBJ LOC harbour 2SG IPFV pay | \glt ‘Everything, you want to remove it from the port, you pay [tax].’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:752} involves the initial, dislocated topical object pronoun mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’, which is reiterated in the object position after sí ‘see’ and anaphorically referred to by a ‘\textsc{1sg.sbj}’: \is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mí}, lɛk háw yu de sí \textbf{mí}, \textbf{a} dɔ́n sí plɛ́nte tín. | \gls 1SG.INDP like how 2SG IPFV see 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ PRF see plenty thing | \glt ‘As for me, as you see me (now), I’ve seen many things (in life).’

Knowledge Point: Certain types of adverbial clauses are more likely to precede their main clauses than to follow them. When such adverbial clauses do precede their main clauses they usually are topical, and may be set off from the following part of the sentence by an intonation break as well. Compare the purpose clause\is{purpose clauses} beginning with fɔ ‘\textsc{prep’} in \REF{ex:key:754}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fɔ} \textbf{tɔ́k} \textbf{Píchi}, yu nó níd fɔ gó skúl. | \gls PREP talk Pichi 2SG NEG need PREP go school | \glt ‘In order to talk Pichi, you don’t need to go to school.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:755} involves the rather rare case of a right-dislocated, topical (and nominalised hence non-finite) clause namely fɔ pút nivel ‘to level the ground’. This last example also shows once more that the transition is smooth to focus marking, since \REF{ex:key:755} may also be seen as an example of pseudo-clefting\is{pseudo-cleft constructions}:\is{resumptive pronouns}
Content 1: \gll Di tín wé bin dé difícil mɔ́ na dí hós, \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{pút} \textbf{nivel}. | \gls DEF thing SUB PST BE.LOC difficult more LOC this house PREP put level | \glt ‘The thing that was most difficult in [building] this house, [was] to level the ground.’
Content 2: \gll Di tín wé bin dé difícil mɔ́ na dí hós, \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{pút} \textbf{nivel}. | \gls DEF thing SUB PST BE.LOC difficult more LOC this house PREP put level | \glt ‘The thing that was most difficult in [building] this house, [was] to level the ground.’

Knowledge Point: Apart from being used to signal topicality, the particle náw ‘now’ is a time adverbial \REF{ex:key:756}, which may occur in presentational sentences like the following:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Náw} e tínap na grɔ́n. | \gls now 3SG.SBJ stand LOC ground | \glt ‘Now it’s standing on the ground.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:757} below is a metacomment in which speaker (dj) classifies the term mɔnt ‘month’ as an English word (a more current Pichi term is mún ‘moon, month’). In this example, the post-posed particle náw signals the topicality of mɔ́nt.
Content 1: \gll “\textbf{Mɔ́nt}” \textbf{náw}, \textbf{e} dɔ́n bí inglés. | \gls month now 3SG.SBJ PRF BE English | \glt ‘As for “mɔnt”, it’s already English.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes we encounter sentences in which the topic is not reiterated in a syntagmatic relation within the clause. In such cases, the topic functions like in many topic-prominent languages: It is adjoined to the clause and provides a referential frame, within which the precise relation between topic and comment is recovered by pragmatic context (cf. \citealt{LiThompson1976}). For example, in \REF{ex:key:758}, the topicality of pikín ‘child(ren)’ is signalled by náw ‘now’ and an intonation break. However, the “resumptive” pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ does not refer to the topical syntactic subject pikín. Instead, e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ refers to a concept as a whole, namely procreation, which is loosely referred to by the topic pikín:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pikín} \textbf{náw}, \textbf{e} nó hád. | \gls child now 3SG.SBJ NEG hard | \glt ‘As for [having] kids, that’s not difficult.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:759} presents the topical and focused \textsc{NP} sósó Píchi ‘only Pichi’, however without the focus marker na ‘\textsc{foc}’. The topic is followed by náw now’ and fronted\is{fronting}. The out-of-focus part of the sentence is exceptionally expressed in a relative clause\is{relative clauses}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sósó} \textbf{Píchi} \textbf{náw} \textbf{wé} wi de tɔ́k. | \gls only Pichi now SUB 1PL IPFV talk | \glt ‘(It was) only Pichi that we used to talk.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:760} below features the \textsc{3sg} personal pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’ under assertive focus by means of clefting and additional topic marking by means of a post-posed náw ‘now’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{ín} \textbf{náw} a bin de chɛ́k sé e bin fɔ dé fáyn if a mít wán pɔ́sin (...) | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP now 1SG.SBJ PST IPFV check QUOT 3SG.SBJ PST COND BE.LOC fine if 1SG.SBJ meet one person (...) | \glt ‘That’s why I was thinking it would be fine if I met somebody (...)’

Knowledge Point: Clauses involving the three core copulas na ‘\textsc{foc}’, nóto ‘\textsc{neg}.\textsc{foc}’ and bí \textit{\textsc{‘be’}} feature a subject, the copula and a nominal complement\is{complements}. The functions of the copula include expression of the identity of two participants \REF{ex:key:761}, and classification as member of a group \REF{ex:key:762}:
Content 1: \gll Dán tín \textbf{na} di pasta. | \gls that thing FOC DEF paste | \glt ‘That thing is the paste.’
Content 2: \gll \'{I}n \textbf{na} kres-húman. | \gls 3SG.INDP FOC be.crazy.CPD-woman | \glt ‘She’s a crazy woman.’

Knowledge Point: Further functions are the attribution of a role \REF{ex:key:763}, a name \REF{ex:key:764}, and the expression of a family relationship \REF{ex:key:765}. Note the presence of the verb tɔ́n ‘turn’ which denotes a change of state when used as a copula verb \REF{ex:key:763}:
Content 1: \gll Mi papá \textbf{na} dɔ́kta bɔt mí nó go \textbf{tɔ́n} dɔ́kta. | \gls 1SG.POSS father FOC doctor but 1SG.INDP NEG POT turn doctor | \glt ‘My father is a doctor but I won’t become a doctor.’
Content 2: \gll Yɛ́s, mi ném \textbf{na} Djunais. | \gls yes 1SG.POSS name FOC NAME | \glt ‘Yes, my name is Djunais.’
Content 3: \gll Na dán tɛ́n a kán sabí sé mi mamá \textbf{na} mi mamá. | \gls FOC that time 1SG.SBJ PFV know QUOT 1SG.POSS mother FOC 1SG.POSS mother | \glt ‘It’s then that I came to know that my mother was my mother.’
Content 4: \gll Mi papá \textbf{na} dɔ́kta bɔt mí nó go \textbf{tɔ́n} dɔ́kta. | \gls 1SG.POSS father FOC doctor but 1SG.INDP NEG POT turn doctor | \glt ‘My father is a doctor but I won’t become a doctor.’

Knowledge Point: Equative clauses\is{equative clauses} are characterised by asymmetries and suppletion in the use of personal pronouns, polarity,\is{negation} and \textsc{TMA} marking. These asymmetries derive from the core function of na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto to express identification in presentational sentences like \REF{ex:key:766} and \REF{ex:key:767}. In these clauses, the identified elements (i.e. kasára ‘cassava’ and wi Píchi ‘our (kind of) Pichi’) are in focus by default. Therefore, I consistently gloss na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto as \textsc{foc} and \textsc{neg.foc,} respectively, in order to render the chiefly pragmatic function of these elements:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} kasára. | \gls FOC cassava | \glt ‘That’s (a) cassava.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{N}\textbf{óto} wi Píchi. | \gls NEG.FOC 1PL Pichi | \glt ‘That’s not our (kind of) Pichi.’

Knowledge Point: However, when identity between a personal pronoun with reference other than \textsc{3sg} and another NP is expressed, the deeply pragmatic nature of the copula-like element in sentences like \REF{ex:key:768} above is revealed. Since na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto is not a copula “verb”, the subject pronoun cannot come from the dependent series of the pronominal paradigm. Instead, an independent emphatic pronoun must be used:
Content 1: \gll In papá \textbf{na} chino. | \gls 3SG.POSS father FOC Chinese | \glt ‘Her father is Chinese.’

Knowledge Point: The two asymmetries in the formation of copula clauses next to negative suppletion (i.e. \ref{ex:key:767} and \textsc{3sg} default reference, i.e. \ref{ex:key:766} and \ref{ex:key:768}) are complemented by a third asymmetry: Whenever overt \textsc{TMA} marking is required or the copula is employed in a context suggesting reduced finiteness\is{finiteness}, the copula verb bí \textit{\textsc{‘be’}} is made use of. This complementary distribution is strict. Therefore, a clause like the following one is ungrammatical, since bí may not appear in basic identity clauses without overt TMA marking. Compare \REF{ex:key:768} above and \REF{ex:key:770} below:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{N}\textbf{óto} wi Píchi. | \gls NEG.FOC 1PL Pichi | \glt ‘That’s not our (kind of) Pichi.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} kasára. | \gls FOC cassava | \glt ‘That’s (a) cassava.’
Content 3: \gll In papá \textbf{na} chino. | \gls 3SG.POSS father FOC Chinese | \glt ‘Her father is Chinese.’
Content 4: \gll In papá \textbf{na} chino. | \gls 3SG.POSS father FOC Chinese | \glt ‘Her father is Chinese.’

Knowledge Point: In the following two equative clauses, the presence of the \textsc{TMA} markers dɔ́n ‘\textsc{prf}’ \REF{ex:key:771} and go ‘\textsc{pot}’ \REF{ex:key:772} motivates the appearance of the suppletive identity copula bí ‘\textsc{be’.} In spite of its defective distribution (cf. \ref{ex:key:770}), the copula bí behaves much more like a copula verb than na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto: It may take dependent personal pronouns (e.g. in \ref{ex:key:771}) and appear with TMA marking (e.g. \ref{ex:key:771} and \ref{ex:key:772}).
Content 1: \gll E \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{bí} wán señorita. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PRF BE one little.lady | \glt ‘She has already become a real young lady.’
Content 2: \gll Mí \textbf{go} \textbf{bí} dɔ́kta. | \gls 1SG.INDP POT BE doctor | \glt ‘I’ll be doctor.’
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll E \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{bí} wán señorita. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PRF BE one little.lady | \glt ‘She has already become a real young lady.’
Content 5: \gll E \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{bí} wán señorita. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PRF BE one little.lady | \glt ‘She has already become a real young lady.’
Content 6: \gll Mí \textbf{go} \textbf{bí} dɔ́kta. | \gls 1SG.INDP POT BE doctor | \glt ‘I’ll be doctor.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:773} below contains two copula clauses. The first one features the copula bí marked for past tense\is{past tense} by bin ‘\textsc{pst}’. In contrast, the second clause is not overtly marked for tense, hence the copula cum focus marker na is employed. Recall that Pichi employs relational tense. Hence the identity copula na may have past tense reference because tense reference has been anchored in the past by the use of bin in the preceding clause. In fact, in this example, a past tense reference of na is a plausible option because the speaker’s mother is deceased (unless the speaker considers reference to her mother to be generic in nature):
Content 1: \gll Mi ném \textbf{bin} \textbf{bí} Francisca Belobe Toichoa, porque mi mamá in ném \textbf{na} Belobe Toichoa. | \gls 1SG.POSS name PST BE NAME NAME NAME because 1SG.POSS mother 3SG.POSS name FOC NAME NAME | \glt ‘My name was Francicsa Belobe Toichoa because my mother’s name is/was Belobe Toichoa.’

Knowledge Point: A further example involving overt TMA marking in an equative clause follows. Sentence \REF{ex:key:774} features the narrative perfective marker kán ‘\textsc{pfv}’ followed by bí ‘\textsc{be’}. Note that the combination of kán ‘\textsc{pfv}’ with the copula bí renders a change of state reading of bí just like with any other (inchoative-)stative verb (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:326}–\ref{ex:key:327}):
Content 1: \gll So mí, mi yón e \textbf{kán} \textbf{bí} una desgracia. | \gls so 1SG.INDP 1SG.POSS own 3SG.SBJ PFV BE DEF disgrace | \glt ‘So as for me, mine [my matter] came to be a disgrace.’
Content 2: \gll Pero ɛf di tín \textbf{kán} \textbf{bɔkú} mɔ́ pás di watá, e go lɛ́f wán pasta. | \gls but if DEF thing PFV much more pass DEF water 3SG.SBJ POT leave one paste | \glt ‘But if the thing has become more than the water, a paste will remain.’
Content 3: \gll E \textbf{kán} \textbf{lɛ́k} ɔ́da húman. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PFV like other woman | \glt ‘(Then) he fell in love with another woman.’

Knowledge Point: Bí \textsc{‘be’} is also employed instead of na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto in contexts of reduced finiteness\is{finiteness}. In \REF{ex:key:775}, bí occurs as the complement of the modal verb fít ‘can’. The form bí also appears in subjunctive\is{subjunctive mood} clauses \REF{ex:key:776}. Such clauses are not only inherently future-referring and non-assertive. They also feature reduced tense-aspect marking and are less finite:
Content 1: \gll “Kɔ́t” \textbf{fít} bí lɛkɛ herida. | \gls cut can BE like wound | \glt ` “Kɔ́t” can be [mean] like a wound.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Mék} e \textbf{bí} sé Kofí dɔ́n kán. | \gls SBJV 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC QUOT NAME PRF come | \glt ‘(Please) let it be that Kofí has come.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, bí is the only identity copula attested in a context like \REF{ex:key:777} below. In the example, the copula occurs in a subordinate clause featuring the clause linker wé ‘\textsc{sub}’. The non-assertive environment of the subordinate clause precludes use of na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto as copulas. This is presumably due to the fact that these particles realise their core function in identificational and presentational sentences, which are assertive structures par excellence.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Frɔn} wé a \textbf{bí} pikín a \textbf{bin} wánt kɔmɔ́t na dís kɔ́ntri. | \gls from SUB 1SG.SBJ BE child 1SG.SBJ PST want go.away LOC this country | \glt ‘From when I was a child, I wanted to leave this country.’

Knowledge Point: Additionally, tense\is{tense} reference of the subordinate clause is dependent on the main clause, which is set in the past. These factors contribute to the use of bí although the context is finite and there is no overt TMA marking in the subordinate clause in \REF{ex:key:777}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Frɔn} wé a \textbf{bí} pikín a \textbf{bin} wánt kɔmɔ́t na dís kɔ́ntri. | \gls from SUB 1SG.SBJ BE child 1SG.SBJ PST want go.away LOC this country | \glt ‘From when I was a child, I wanted to leave this country.’

Knowledge Point: The copula dé may occur in intransitive clauses without any complement. Such clauses show that dé is semantically relatively rich and has a meaning of its own, namely ‘exist in a place’ or ‘exist in a certain manner’. Compare the question in \REF{ex:key:779a} and the corresponding answer in \REF{ex:key:779b}:
Content 1: \gll Ebongolo \textbf{dé}? | \gls NAME BE.LOC | \glt ‘Is Ebongolo around/his usual self/fine/alright?’
Content 2: \gll Yɛ́s, e \textbf{dé}. | \gls yes 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC | \glt ‘Yes, he’s here/around/his usual self/fine/alright.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:780}, dé takes a locative adverbial phrase introduced by the general locative preposition na ‘\textsc{loc}’ as a complement. The adverbial phrase in \REF{ex:key:781} involves the locative noun nía ‘be near’:
Content 1: \gll E \textbf{dé} \textbf{na} \textbf{grɔ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC LOC ground | \glt ‘He is [lying] on the ground.’
Content 2: \gll Yu fon \textbf{dé} \textbf{nía} \textbf{tébul}. | \gls 2SG phone BE.LOC near table | \glt ‘Your phone is near the table.’

Knowledge Point: Locative complements of dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ other than locative adverbs like yandá ‘yonder’ in \REF{ex:key:782} rarely appear without a preposition or a locative noun. Where they do, the absence of the locative noun is usually lexically determined. Compare dé láyf ‘\textsc{be.loc} life’ = ‘be alive’ in \REF{ex:key:783}. Also note that the copula dé receives an imperfective, present tense\is{present tense} interpretation like any other unmarked stative verb in Pichi:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta dí wán wé e \textbf{dé} \textbf{yandá}, e bíg. | \gls then this one SUB 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC yonder 3SG.SBJ be.big | \glt ‘Then, that one that’s over there, it’s big.’
Content 2: \gll Somos tú dásɔl wé wi \textbf{dé} \textbf{láyf}. | \gls we.are two only SUB 1PL BE.LOC life | \glt ‘We are only two who are alive.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:784} exemplifies how dé is used to express existence in time. In contrast to locative complements, time adverbials like ívin tɛ́n ‘evening’ appear as direct complements of the copula dé when the intended meaning is ‘location{\fff} in time’ (cf. \sectref{sec:8.2.2} for other temporal relations):
Content 1: \gll Wi \textbf{dé} \textbf{íbin} \textbf{tɛ́n}. | \gls 1PL BE.LOC evening time | \glt ‘It’s evening.’

Knowledge Point: Further, the time is always told in a codemixed Pichi-Spanish construction. The noun phrase employed in telling the time in \ili{Spanish} appears as a complement of the copula dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ which in turn takes a \textsc{1pl} subject \REF{ex:key:785}. No prepositions are employed in this construction either. Hence here too, there is no formal indication of the adverbial status of the time expression:
Content 1: \gll Wi \textbf{dé} \textbf{las} \textbf{dos} \textbf{y} \textbf{media}. | \gls 1PL BE.LOC the.PL two and half | \glt ‘It’s two thirty.’

Knowledge Point: The form dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ may also be employed to attribute a relatively transient, non-time-stable property to a subject. Hence, dé is encountered as a predicator in predicate adjective constructions involving the few adjectives that Pichi has. One of these is fáyn ‘(be) fine’ in \REF{ex:key:786}. As explained in detail in \sectref{sec:7.6.5}, predicate adjective constructions, rather than verbal clauses, are only chosen when the situation is perceived as non-time-stable:
Content 1: \gll Dán tɛ́n a \textbf{dé} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls that time 1SG.SBJ BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘That time I was [feeling] fine.’

Knowledge Point: Another manifestation of the non-time stable character of the situation predicated by dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ is given in the following three sentences. The copula dé is used when an adverbial complement designates a way of being rather than intrinsic being. Adverbial complements can be a simple manner adverb like só ‘so’ \REF{ex:key:787}, a bare noun phrase featuring the generic noun stáyl ‘manner, style’ \REF{ex:key:788}, or a prepositional phrase with the similative{\fff} and equative preposition lɛk ‘like’ \REF{ex:key:789}:
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{só} e \textbf{dé}. | \gls FOC like.that 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC | \glt ‘That’s the way it is.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{dé} \textbf{ɔ́da} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC other style | \glt ‘It’s different.’
Content 3: \gll A wánt \textbf{dé} \textbf{lɛk} Miguel Ángel. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want BE.LOC like NAME NAME | \glt ‘I want to be like Miguel Ángel [the way he dresses/acts/looks].’

Knowledge Point: By extension, dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ is also employed whenever an attributed property is questioned directly \REF{ex:key:790} and indirectly \REF{ex:key:791}, or when a property is attributed to a main clause verb in a free adverbial manner clause\is{manner clauses} \REF{ex:key:792}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Háw} yu go \textbf{dé}, yu nó gɛ́t pikín? | \gls how 2SG POT there 2SG NEG get child | \glt ‘How would you be [feel] (if) you had no child?’
Content 2: \gll Bɔt mí wánt sabí \textbf{háw} dán tín \textbf{dé}. | \gls but 1SG.INDP want know how that thing BE.LOC | \glt ‘But I [EMP] wanted to know how that thing was.’
Content 3: \gll Yu gɛ́fɔ lɛ́f=an \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{háw} e \textbf{dé}. | \gls 2SG have.to leave=3SG.OBJ like how 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC | \glt ‘You have to leave it how it is.’

Knowledge Point: Contrary to the time stable copulas na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto and bí described above, dé exhibits no irregularities with respect to \textsc{TMA} marking and negation\is{negation} \REF{ex:key:793}. It occurs with the standard negator and any \textsc{TMA} marker compatible with its distribution as a stative verb \REF{ex:key:794}:
Content 1: \gll Nó bɔ́dí \textbf{nó} \textbf{dé} na pueblo. | \gls NEG body NEG BE.LOC LOC village | \glt ‘Nobody is in the village.’
Content 2: \gll Sé “ús=tín \textbf{kin} \textbf{dé} ínsay dé?” | \gls QUOT Q=thing HAB BE.LOC inside there | \glt ‘(They) said “what is usually in there?”‘

Knowledge Point: When employed as a lexical verb, tɔ́n means ‘turn, stir’ \REF{ex:key:796}. In its literal sense, tɔ́n is employed as a dynamic verb with an agent subject and a patient\is{patient} object \REF{ex:key:795}, or a locative adverbial \REF{ex:key:796}. The collocation tɔ́n bák means ‘return’ \REF{ex:key:797}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Tɔ́n} na yu lɛ́f-hán! | \gls turn LOC DEF left.CPD-hand | \glt ‘Turn left!’
Content 2: \gll Yu gɛ́fɔ de \textbf{tɔ́n}=an. | \gls 2SG have.to IPFV turn=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You have to be stirring it.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Tɔ́n} na yu lɛ́f-hán! | \gls turn LOC DEF left.CPD-hand | \glt ‘Turn left!’
Content 4: \gll Mék a gó dú smɔ́l tín a \textbf{tɔ́n} \textbf{bák}. | \gls SBJV 1SG.SBJ go do be.small thing 1SG.SBJ turn back | \glt ‘Let me go do something quickly (and) come back.’

Knowledge Point: As a copula verb, tɔ́n ‘turn’ designates a change of state from one identity to another \REF{ex:key:798}:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn-ɔ́l dɛn dɔ́n \textbf{tɔ́n} \textbf{europeos} \textbf{dɛn}. | \gls 3PL.CPD-all 3PL PRF turn European.PL PL | \glt ‘They have all turned into Europeans.’

Knowledge Point: In contexts other than copula expression and causative formation, lɛ́f may be employed as a dynamic verb in transitive clauses with the meaning ‘leave (behind)’ \REF{ex:key:799}:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{lɛ́f} di tín dɛn di sáy wé yu bin tɛ́l mí. | \gls 1SG.SBJ leave DEF thing PL DEF side SUB 2SG PST tell 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘I left the things where you told me to.’

Knowledge Point: Besides the verb gɛ́t ‘get, have’ (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.3}), a few other verbs express existence in space and time. When the inchoative-stative verb lɛ́f ‘leave, remain’ occurs in an intransitive clause featuring a comitative or locative adverbial, this verb assumes a copula function with the meaning ‘remain (behind), stay temporarily with’ \REF{ex:key:801}.
Content 1: \gll Machyta \textbf{lɛ́f} wet in fámbul. | \gls NAME remain with 3SG.POSS family | \glt ‘Machyta has remained (temporarily) with his family’

Knowledge Point: The verb kɔmɔ́t ‘come out’ is employed to indicate a change of state in lexicalised collocations involving associative objects\is{associative objects} (cf. also \sectref{sec:9.3.2}). Compare \REF{ex:key:802}:
Content 1: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} de trén=an porque e go \textbf{kɔmɔ́t} pɔ́sin. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV train=3SG.OBJ because 3SG.SBJ POT come.out person | \glt ‘I’m bringing him up because [so that] he will turn out to be a (responsible) person.’

Knowledge Point: The dynamic verb sté means ‘last (a long time)’ as in \REF{ex:key:803}. This verb also expresses excessive duration in an adverbial SVC (cf. \sectref{sec:11.2.5}):
Content 1: \gll Bɛ́ta tín nó de \textbf{sté}. | \gls very.good thing NEG IPFV last | \glt ‘Good things don’t last.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, the occurrence of pás ‘pass’ and rích ‘arrive’ as inchoative-stative verbs in comparatives like \REF{ex:key:483} and equatives like \REF{ex:key:510} may also be seen as manifestations of a copula-like use of these otherwise dynamic verbs.\is{copula verb}
Content 1: \gll Di pikín \textbf{pás} yú \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{sɛ́ns}. | \gls DEF child pass 2SG.INDP PREP brain | \glt ‘The child is more intelligent than you.’
Content 2: \gll E nó \textbf{rích} mí \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG arrive 1SG.INDP PREP fine | \glt ‘He doesn’t equal me in beauty.’

Knowledge Point: The gɛ́t-existential construction occurs in a transitive clause. The subject position is filled by an expletive \textsc{3sg} pronoun, the object position by the existing entity \REF{ex:key:804}. This construction exclusively serves the expression of existential meaning and has no locative connotation. None of the other constructions that follow are uniquely employed to express existential meaning in this way:
Content 1: \gll Dís smɔ́l bɔ́tul dɛn Fanta, wé e \textbf{gɛ́t} Coca-Cola, e \textbf{gɛ́t} Fanta, e \textbf{gɛ́t} limón, e báy=an wán. | \gls this small bottle PL NAME SUB 3SG.SBJ get NAME 3SG.SBJ get NAME 3SG.SBJ get lemon 3SG.SBJ buy=3SG.OBJ one | \glt ‘These small bottles of Fanta, where there is Coca-Cola, there is Fanta, there is Lemon, she bought him one (of them).’

Knowledge Point: Pichi has other ways of establishing the type of impersonal reference characteristic for gɛ́t-existentials besides a \textsc{3sg} expletive pronoun{\fff}. The verb gɛ́t may also occur with an impersonal \textsc{3pl} \REF{ex:key:805} or \textsc{2sg} \REF{ex:key:806} pronoun in clauses that are functionally similar to existentials \REF{ex:key:804}:{\fff}
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Bɔt yu dɔ́n sabí na Afrika \textbf{yu} \textbf{nó} \textbf{gɛ́t} nó relación fɔ mán lɛk na Europa. | \gls but 2SG PRF know LOC PLACE 2SG NEG get NEG relation PREP man like LOC Europe | \glt ‘But you already know that in Africa you don’t have a relationship with a man like in Europe.’
Content 3: \gll Dís smɔ́l bɔ́tul dɛn Fanta, wé e \textbf{gɛ́t} Coca-Cola, e \textbf{gɛ́t} Fanta, e \textbf{gɛ́t} limón, e báy=an wán. | \gls this small bottle PL NAME SUB 3SG.SBJ get NAME 3SG.SBJ get NAME 3SG.SBJ get lemon 3SG.SBJ buy=3SG.OBJ one | \glt ‘These small bottles of Fanta, where there is Coca-Cola, there is Fanta, there is Lemon, she bought him one (of them).’

Knowledge Point: There are no restrictions on the use of gɛ́t-existentials in subordinate clauses. In sentence \REF{ex:key:807}, the existential clause appears in a relative clause introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’:
Content 1: \gll Bɔt na dán fɔ́s tɛ́n hós dɛn \textbf{wé} e \textbf{gɛ́t} dá piso dɛn fɔ dán altura dɛn. | \gls but FOC that first time house PL SUB 3SG.SBJ get that storey PL PREP that height PL | \glt ‘But its those houses of the past where there are those high storeys’

Knowledge Point: Copula clauses\is{copula!locative-existential} featuring dé \textsc{‘be.loc’} typically acquire an existential reading when they lack a copula complement\is{complements!copula complements}. In these clauses, we find the predicated entity, which may be of varying complexity, in the subject position \REF{ex:key:808}. Since there is no complement to provide further specification, the clause acquires the default locative and manner reading that typifies such dé{}-clauses \REF{ex:key:809}:
Content 1: \gll Bueno aunque dé, \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{interés} \textbf{económico} \textbf{dé}. | \gls good although there much interest economic BE.LOC | \glt ‘Alright although there, there’s a lot of economic interest.’
Content 2: \gll Bueno, \textbf{mi} \textbf{gran-pá} bin \textbf{dé}. | \gls good 1SG.POSS grand-pa PST BE.LOC | \glt ‘Alright, my grandfather was around/fine.’

Knowledge Point: Hence, constructions featuring dé acquire a locative reading when a locative expression is present. In \REF{ex:key:810}, we find the locative adverbial na sala ‘in the hall’:
Content 1: \gll Paciente dɛn \textbf{dé} \textbf{na} \textbf{sala}, yú dɔ́kta la una yu de kán? | \gls patient PL BE.LOC LOC hall 2SG.INDP doctor the one 2SG IPFV come | \glt ‘Patients are in the hall, (and) you doctor, it’s (only) at one o’clock that you come?’

Knowledge Point: Existential clauses featuring gɛ́t are not often negated. The data contains only a single negative gɛ́t-existential clause, presented in \REF{ex:key:811}. This is probably so because the “true” existential construction featuring gɛ́t is subject to an affirmative presupposition:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn de kɔ́l dɛn sé, \textbf{e} \textbf{nó} \textbf{gɛ́t} tɔ́k na Píchi. | \gls 3PL IPFV call 3PL QUOT 3SG.SBJ NEG get talk LOC Pichi | \glt ‘They’re called, there is no word (for that) in Pichi.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, the corpus does not reveal any instance of a non-finite gɛ́t with an existential sense. Conversely, we once more encounter many examples of non-finite dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ with an existential reading as in \REF{ex:key:814}:
Content 1: \gll Ebanistas dɛn \textbf{gɛ́fɔ} \textbf{dé}. | \gls Carpenter.PL PL have.to BE.LOC | \glt ‘Carpenters have to be there/around.’

Knowledge Point: The same applies to TMA marking. While quite a few dé-existentials are found with overt TMA marking as in \REF{ex:key:815}, there is no such example of a gɛ́t-existential. The latter type of existential therefore appears to be prototypical in an additional sense – gɛ́t existentials typically predicate a generic situation, which is also marked as such by factative{\fff} tense-aspect:
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́ wán accidente fɔ motó \textbf{bin} \textbf{dé}. | \gls INTJ one accident PREP car PST BE.LOC | \glt ‘Oh yes, there was a car accident.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, it is useful to draw attention to the linkages between existential and factive clauses. Factive clauses featuring the copula dé are existential clauses with a referentially empty subject position and a complement clause\is{complement clause} introduced by sé ‘\textsc{quot}’. The subject is either an expletive e ‘\textsc{3sg}’ or a dummy noun\is{dummy noun} like tín ‘thing’, as in this example (cf. eg. \ref{ex:key:1139} for further details on factive clauses):
Content 1: \gll Na só \textbf{e} \textbf{dé}. | \gls FOC like.that 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC | \glt ‘That’s how it is.’

Knowledge Point: The verb gɛ́t ‘get, have’ expresses permanent, time-stable possession. When gɛ́t occurs in a factative marked clause \REF{ex:key:817}, a lexicalised light verb construction \REF{ex:key:818}, an existential construction (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.3}), or other contexts that propose a generic reading, the verb leans towards the stative meaning ‘own, be in permanent possession’:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{gɛ́t} mɔdɛlɔ́. | \gls 1SG.SBJ get mother-in-law | \glt ‘I have a mother-in-law.’
Content 2: \gll Dí mán \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{líba} ɛ́n, fɔ kɔmɔ́t wet dís káyn bíg gɛ́l. | \gls this man get liver INTJ PREP go.out with this kind big girl | \glt ‘Than man has guts, right, to go out with such an influential girl.’

Knowledge Point: Conversely, when gɛ́t co-occurs with a TMA marker with a default or explicit perfective reading \REF{ex:key:819} or sentential aspect suggestive of telicity (i.e. the time clause in \ref{ex:key:820}), an inchoative interpretation of gɛ́t as ‘acquire, enter into permanent possession’ is favoured:
Content 1: \gll Di papá de gládin sé in pikín \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{gɛ́t} wók. | \gls DEF father IPFV be.glad QUOT 3SG.POSS child PRF get work | \glt ‘The father is happy that his child has found work.’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{kin} \textbf{gɛ́t} mɔní, a kin fála húman dɛn. | \gls 1SG.SBJ HAB get money 1SG.SBJ HAB follow woman PL | \glt ‘(When) I used to receive money, I would chase women.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes we also find the phrases dé fɔ ‘\textsc{be.loc} \textsc{prep}’ \is{copula!locative-existential}or na fɔ ‘\textsc{be.loc} \textsc{prep}’ \is{copula!identity}expressing time-stable possession. There is no difference in meaning between the two constructions, although na ‘\textsc{foc}’ is employed as a time-stable identity copula in other contexts \REF{ex:key:822}:
Content 1: \gll Di tín \textbf{dé} \textbf{fɔr}=an, di tín \textbf{na} \textbf{fɔ} ín. | \gls DEF thing BE.LOC PREP=3SG.OBJ DEF THING FOC PREP 3SG.INDP | \glt ‘The thing is his, the thing is his (...)’

Knowledge Point: The verb hól ‘hold, keep’ expresses non-time-stable, temporary possession in a transitive clause like \REF{ex:key:823}. In such contexts, it is best translated as ‘keep’. The temporary nature of possession expressed by hól is reaffirmed by the adverbial phrase durante un mes entero ‘for one whole month’, which specifies the period of possession:
Content 1: \gll A fít \textbf{hól} dán mɔní \textbf{durante} \textbf{un} \textbf{mes} \textbf{entero}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ can keep that money during DEF month whole | \glt ‘I’m able to keep that money for a whole month.’

Knowledge Point: Speaker (dj) summarises the difference between gɛ́t and hól in \REF{ex:key:824}. Note the difference in aspect marking with hól, gɛ́t, and dráyb ‘drive’. Imperfective{\fff} aspect is expressed through factative{\fff} marking with the inchoative-stative verbs hól and gɛ́t. Meanwhile, it is the presence of de ‘\textsc{ipfv}’ that signals imperfective aspect with the dynamic verb dráyb:
Content 1: \gll “Yu \textbf{hól} wán motó”, yu de dráyb=an, pero sé yu gɛ́t, cuando tienes, “a \textbf{gɛ́t} wán motó”. | \gls 2SG hold one car 2SG IPFV drive=3SG.OBJ but QUOT 2SG get when you.get 1SG.SBJ get one car | \glt ` “Yú hól wán motó” (means) you’re driving it, but when you possess it, when you have it “a gɛ́t wán motó.”’

Knowledge Point: The notion of temporary possession expressed by hól ‘hold, keep’ may also be applied to a human-possessed \textsc{NP}. A characteristic of West African pedagogy is to confer responsibility for the upbringing of a child to members of the extended family other than the biological parents. Such temporary guardianship is also expressed by hól. I leave it to speaker (au) to explain the meaning of hól in sentences \REF{ex:key:825} and \REF{ex:key:826}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Bikɔs e \textbf{hól} yú na hós yu gɛ́fɔ gɛ́t di hóm trénin. | \gls because 3SG.SBJ hold 2SG.INDP LOC house 2SG have.to get DEF home training | \glt ‘Because she has guardianship over you in her house you have to receive home education.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:830}, fáyn ‘be fine’ is used as an adjective and denotes a physical property, namely a body state in an intransitive clause. The predicate adjective construction featuring the copula dé translates as ‘be fine, well, healthy’. Contrast this meaning with \REF{ex:key:831}, where fáyn is employed as an inchoative-stative verb with the meaning ‘be intrinsically fine’ hence ‘beautiful’. In the latter example, fáyn therefore denotes a value:
Content 1: \gll Tidé di húman \textbf{dé} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls today DEF woman BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘Today the woman is fine.’
Content 2: \gll Di húman \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls DEF woman be.fine | \glt ‘The woman is beautiful.’

Knowledge Point: The words in the second and third columns of \tabref{tab:key:7.11} appear as predicate adjectives in the corpus only rarely. For example, the property item bráyt ‘be bright, glowing with beauty’ is attested as an adjective where it denotes a visible body state as in \REF{ex:key:832} – the speaker is an elderly lady giving an account of her youth. Compare frɛ́s ‘be fresh’ in the same sentence, which is used as an inchoative-stative verb to denote a more lasting body state of freshness or youthfulness:
Content 1: \gll Moka bɔ́y dɛn krés wé dɛn sí lɛk háw a frɛ́s, na so a \textbf{dé} \textbf{bráyt}. | \gls PLACE boy PL go.mad SUB 3PL see like how 1SG.SBJ be.fresh FOC like.that 1SG.SBJ BE.LOC bright | \glt ‘The Moka boys went crazy when they saw how fresh I was, that’s how bright I looked.’

Knowledge Point: The physical property item wɔwɔ́ ‘be ugly, messed up’ is used by the same speaker as an adjective in \REF{ex:key:834} and as an inchoative-stative verb in \REF{ex:key:835}. The first example featuring wɔwɔ́ again expresses a visible state of the street, while the second is more time-stable in its meaning:
Content 1: \gll Di strít \textbf{dé} \textbf{wɔwɔ́}. | \gls DEF street BE.LOC ugly | \glt ‘The street looks messed up.’
Content 2: \gll Di strít \textbf{wɔwɔ́}, di strít \textbf{chakrá}, di strít nó \textbf{dé} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls DEF street be.ugly DEF street be.destroyed DEF street NEG BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘The street is messed up, the street is destroyed, the street is not fine.’

Knowledge Point: Predicate adjective clauses may be marked for \textsc{TMA} like any other copula clause featuring the copula dé. Compare the adjective bád ‘ill’ in \REF{ex:key:836} with a future tens\is{future tense}e reference:
Content 1: \gll Wé yu go fɔdɔ́n yu \textbf{go} \textbf{dé} \textbf{bád}. | \gls SUB 2SG POT fall 2SG POT BE.LOC bad | \glt ‘When you fall you’ll be in a bad state.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, I draw attention to the various other means of attributing properties to a noun. Speakers make use of postnominal modification through relative or quotative clause{\fff}s. Other ways of expressing modification are associative constructions and compounding{\fff}. Two strategies of modification serve as a productive means of deriving new property items next to the use of Spanish adjectives in the Pichi predicate adjective construction. A dé-copula clause with an adverbial complement {\fff}featuring wet ‘with’ \REF{ex:key:838}, as well as light verb constructions involving gɛ́t ‘get, have’ \REF{ex:key:839} allow the attribution of a property to a referent:
Content 1: \gll E hád fɔ mék mék dɛn bíl na yá só bikɔs di grɔ́n e tú \textbf{dé} \textbf{wet} \textbf{stón}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ be.hard PREP make SBJV 3PL build LOC here like.that because DEF ground 3SG.SBJ too BE.LOC with stone | \glt It’s hard for them to build here because the ground is too stony.’
Content 2: \gll E hád fɔ bíl na yá bikɔs sé di grɔ́n \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{sansán}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ be.hard PREP build LOC here because QUOT DEF ground get much sand | \glt ‘It’s hard to build here because the ground is very sandy.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbs that appear at the beginning modify the sentence in its entirety – they have a wide scope. In \REF{ex:key:840}, the linking adverb adverb pero ‘but’, the modal adverb sɔntɛ́n ‘perhaps’, and the time adverb bambáy ‘gradually’ all occur sentence-initially:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pero} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{sɔntɛ́n} yu go sí di wán wé go máred yú. | \gls but gradually REP perhaps 2SG POT see DEF one SUB POT marry 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘But very gradually perhaps you might find the one who will marry you.’

Knowledge Point: Locative and time adverbs may also occur after the verb, in which case they have narrow scope and modify the meaning of the verb alone. In \REF{ex:key:841}, the repeated locative noun dɔ́n ‘down’ and the locative adverb yandá ‘yonder’ modify the verb sidɔ́n ‘sit, stay’:
Content 1: \gll Bɔt ín sidɔ́n \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{yandá}. | \gls but 3SG.INDP stay down REP REP yonder | \glt ‘But he stays far down over there.’

Knowledge Point: The data contains diverse time adverbs. A few of these are monomorphemic, e.g. bambáy ‘gradually’ in \REF{ex:key:840} above. Others are more or less idiosyncratic phrases containing the time-denoting generic noun tɛ́n ‘time’, as in bɔkú tɛ́n ‘much time’ = ‘for a long time’ \REF{ex:key:842} or dé ‘day’, as in wán dé ‘someday’ \REF{ex:key:843}. Location{\fff}-in-time adverbs, like wán dé prefer the clause-initial, duration adverbs like lɔ́n tɛ́n ‘long ago’ and bɔkú tɛ́n the clause-final position:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pero} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{sɔntɛ́n} yu go sí di wán wé go máred yú. | \gls but gradually REP perhaps 2SG POT see DEF one SUB POT marry 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘But very gradually perhaps you might find the one who will marry you.’
Content 2: \gll Nó chɛ́k=an \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{tɛ́n}, tɛ́l mí sé nó. | \gls NEG think=3SG.OBJ much time tell 1SG.INDP QUOT NEG | \glt ‘Don’t think about it for a long time, tell me “no”.’
Content 3: \gll Na ín \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé} a bin tɛ́l wán grand frère na, na mi colegio dé, (...) | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP one day 1SG.SBJ PST tell one big brother LOC LOC 1SG.POSS college there (...) | \glt ‘That’s why one day, I told one of my seniors in, in my secondary school there, (...)’

Knowledge Point: The phrase e fínis ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj} finish’ = ‘then’ is a stand-alone clause, which may function as a linking “adverb” \REF{ex:key:846}. A formal indication of its hybrid status between clause and adverb is that the personal pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ is sometimes dropped:
Content 1: \gll A gó wás wet mi hán mí sénwe a dráy=an, \textbf{e} \textbf{fínis} a áyɛn=an. | \gls 1SG.SBJ go wash with 1SG.POSS hand 1SG.INDP EMP 1SG.SBJ dry=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ finish 1SG.SBJ iron=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I myself went to wash (it) with my own hands, I dried it, then ironed it.’

Knowledge Point: The two modal adverbs sɔntɛ́n ‘perhaps’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:840} above) and smɔ́ltɛn ‘nearly’ \REF{ex:key:848} and the evaluative adverb bádtɛn ‘unfortunately’ \REF{ex:key:847} are lexicalised phrases involving the generic noun tɛ́n ‘time’ as a formative element (cf. \ref{ex:key:103} above). Modal and evaluative adverbs are normally found in the initial position with scope over the entire clause:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pero} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{bambáy} \textbf{sɔntɛ́n} yu go sí di wán wé go máred yú. | \gls but gradually REP perhaps 2SG POT see DEF one SUB POT marry 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘But very gradually perhaps you might find the one who will marry you.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Smɔ́ltɛn} a bin fɔ dáy dé. | \gls nearly 1SG.SBJ PST COND die there | \glt ‘I nearly died there.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Bádtɛn} náw, di fɔ́s dɔ́kta wé wi gɛ́t, e nó dé ɔ́p na ɔspítul. | \gls unfortunately now DEF first doctor SUB 1PL get 3SG.SBJ NEG BE.LOC up LOC hospital | \glt ‘Unfortunately, the first doctor that we had wasn’t up (there) in the hospital.’

Knowledge Point: The adverb mébi ‘maybe’ \REF{ex:key:849} is not as common as sɔntɛ́n ‘perhaps’. Note that smɔ́ltɛn \{small.time\} has an entirely opaque sense ‘nearly’ in the example above, and a more transparent, temporal sense ‘shortly (after)’ in \REF{ex:key:850} below.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mébi} dɛn nó go bɛ́g yú plɛ́nte fɔ pé (...) | \gls maybe 3PL NEG POT beg 2SG.INDP plenty PREP pay (...) | \glt ‘Maybe they won’t ask you to pay a lot (...)’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Smɔ́ltɛn} e mék hɛɛɛ. | \gls shortly 3SG.SBJ make ‘exhalation’ | \glt ‘Shortly after, he made [imitates exhalation].’

Knowledge Point: The L-toned clause-initial linking adverb so ‘so’ \REF{ex:key:851} differs from the H-toned deictic manner adverb só ‘like this, like that’ \REF{ex:key:852} in tone alone. The deictic manner adverb so ‘like this’ is often focused and fronted in a na cleft construction, in order to establish reference to preceding discourse material \REF{ex:key:853} (cf. also \sectref{sec:7.4.3.3}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{So} di ɔ́da wán de lístin=an. | \gls So DEF other one IPFV listen=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘So the other one is listening to him.’
Content 2: \gll E de pás \textbf{só} lɛk sé e nó nó mí mɔ́. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV pass like.this like QUOT 3SG.SBJ NEG know 1SG.INDP more | \glt ‘She was passing by just like that as if she didn’t know me anymore.’
Content 3: \gll Na \textbf{só} dɛn go mék yú. | \gls FOC like.this 3PL POT make 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘That’s what they would do to you.’

Knowledge Point: The H-toned adverb só ‘like that’ is also found in the conventionalised collocations (na) yá só ‘right here’ \REF{ex:key:854} and náw só ‘right now’ \REF{ex:key:855}, where its deictic character provides emphasis:
Content 1: \gll Frɔn \textbf{na} \textbf{yá} \textbf{só} dɛn kin controla di húman. | \gls from LOC here like.that 3PL HAB control DEF woman | \glt ‘They control the woman from right here.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Náw} \textbf{só} taksí, nó extranjero nó de drɛ́b taksí mɔ́. | \gls now like.that taxi NEG foreigner NEG IPFV drive taxi more | \glt ‘Right now, as for taxis, no foreigner drives taxis anymore.’

Knowledge Point: Preverbal degree adverbs usually occur with gradable property items or light verb constructions which attribute properties as in \REF{ex:key:859}. Hence, sentences like \REF{ex:key:860}, in which a non-gradable verb (i.e. tɔ́k ‘talk’), and a dynamic one at that, is preceded by a preverbal degree adverb, are very rare:
Content 1: \gll Yu \textbf{tú} \textbf{lɛ́k} húman. | \gls 2SG too like woman | \glt ‘You’re too much of a womaniser.’
Content 2: \gll E fíba lɛk sé a dɔ́n de \textbf{tú} \textbf{tɔ́k} bɔkú. | \gls 3SG.SBJ resemble like QUOT 1SG.SBJ PRF IPFV too talk much | \glt ‘It seems like I’m talking to much.’

Knowledge Point: Non-gradable verbs are more likely to be modified postverbally by the expression tú mɔ́ch ‘too much’ than by preverbal tú ‘too (much)’ \REF{ex:key:861}. The phrase tú mɔ́ch includes the quantifying adverb mɔ́ch. When a verb is modified in this way for superlative degree, the use of mɔ́ch is mandatory. The same applies when tú mɔ́ch modifies a nominal \REF{ex:key:862}:
Content 1: \gll E de só in sɛ́f \textbf{tú} \textbf{mɔ́ch}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV show 3SG.POSS self too much | \glt ‘He boasts too much.’
Content 2: \gll A de fíl \textbf{tú} \textbf{mɔ́ch} \textbf{hɔ́t}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV feel too much heat | \glt ‘I’m feeling too hot [too much heat].’

Knowledge Point: Somewhat similar to the distribution of tú (mɔ́ch) is that of the adverb só ‘like that, that much’. When só occurs in a preverbal position, it implicitly expresses equative degree and means ‘that much’ \REF{ex:key:864}. However, when só appears in the clause-final position, it means ‘like that’ and therefore retains its central meaning as a manner adverb (cf. \ref{ex:key:852} above):\is{preverbal adverbs}
Content 1: \gll Dɛn nó de \textbf{só} \textbf{yús=}an mɔ́. | \gls 3PL NEG IPFV like.that use=3SG.OBJ more | \glt ‘It’s not used that much anymore.’
Content 2: \gll E de pás \textbf{só} lɛk sé e nó nó mí mɔ́. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV pass like.this like QUOT 3SG.SBJ NEG know 1SG.INDP more | \glt ‘She was passing by just like that as if she didn’t know me anymore.’

Knowledge Point: The word mɔ́ ‘be more, again’ also functions as a degree adverb and is characterised by an unusual amount of syntactic flexibility. In contexts other than comparison, mɔ́ may occur clause-finally as a time adverb with the meaning ‘again’ \REF{ex:key:865} and ‘still’ (\ref{ex:key:866}–\ref{ex:key:867}):
Content 1: \gll Pút=an bihɛ́n \textbf{mɔ́}! | \gls put=3SG.OBJ behind more | \glt ‘Put it behind [rewind] again!’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn sé nóto ín wán, ɔ́da wán dé \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls 3PL QUOT NEG.FOC 3SG.INDP one other one BE.LOC more | \glt ‘They said it’s not her alone, there’s yet another one.’
Content 3: \gll E de sigue \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV continue more | \glt ‘It’s still continuing.’

Knowledge Point: In negative clauses, mɔ́ is best translated as ‘anymore, no longer, not again’. Compare the following examples with the negated dynamic verb ánsa ‘answer’ \REF{ex:key:868}, and \REF{ex:key:869} with the negated stative verb and copula dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’:
Content 1: \gll E dé e nó de \textbf{ánsa} mí \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC 3SG.SBJ NEG IPFV answer 1SG.INDP more | \glt ‘She was (just) there (and) wasn’t responding to me any more.’
Content 2: \gll Frɔn Rebola bajando e nó go \textbf{dé} \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls from PLACE descending 3SG.SBJ NEG POT BE.LOC more | \glt ‘As we descend from Rebola, it [the fog] won’t be there anymore.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:870} below mɔ́ may be analysed as occupying the object position of tɔ́k ‘talk, say’ with the meaning ‘more’. Alternatively, mɔ́ may be seen to function as an adverbial and be translated as ‘still, again continue to’:
Content 1: \gll A nó de \textbf{tɔ́k} \textbf{mɔ́}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV talk more | \glt ‘I was not talking any longer.’ OR ‘I was not saying (anything) more/again.’

Knowledge Point: The scope of mɔ́ may also be narrower than the clause. In \REF{ex:key:871}, mɔ́ is in the postnominal position and modifies the preceding NP in a way no different from that of the focus particle sɛ́f ‘\textsc{foc}’ or the quantifier{\fff} ɔ́l ’all’. In \REF{ex:key:872}, mɔ́ modifies the adverbial áfta ‘then’:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nó} \textbf{pát} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{wɔ́l} \textbf{mɔ́} nó dé. | \gls NEG part PREP world more NEG BE.LOC | \glt ‘There is no other part of the world [where it’s like that].’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\'{A}fta mɔ́} a bin wók dís sén wók wé a de dú. | \gls then more 1SG.SBJ PST work this same work SUB 1SG.SBJ IPFV do | \glt ‘Then, additionally, I worked this same job that I’m doing (now).’

Knowledge Point: Besides the adverbs treated so far, compounds \REF{ex:key:873} or constructions featuring generic nouns of place (i.e. sáy ‘side, place’), time (i.e. tɛ́n ‘time’ and dé ‘day’), and manner (i.e. stáyl ‘manner, style’) serve as locative{\fff}, time \REF{ex:key:874}, and manner adverbials \REF{ex:key:875}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wok-sáy} a de híɛ wé dɛn de tɔ́k=an bɔkú. | \gls work.CPD-side 1SG.SBJ IPFV hear SUB 3PL IPFV talk=3SG.OBJ much | \glt ‘(At) work I hear them talk it [Ghanaian Pidgin English] a lot.’
Content 2: \gll E kán \textbf{sán} \textbf{tɛ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ come sun time | \glt ‘He came (at) noon.’
Content 3: \gll Dɛn só di sɔ́t \textbf{tú} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3PL sew DEF shirt two style | \glt ‘The shirt was sewn in two (different) ways.’

Knowledge Point: The corpus contains only few underived manner adverbs (amongst them kwík ‘quickly, early’ in \ref{ex:key:856} above). Nevertheless, the possibilities for providing manner modification are particularly rich. They encompass the use of adverbials, ideophones\is{ideophones}, SVCs, secondary predication, compounds, associative constructions, lexicalised iteration, and adverbial clauses of manner.
Content 1: \gll Bɔt dá mɔní de fínis \textbf{kwík}. | \gls but that money IPFV finish quickly | \glt ‘But that money used to finish quickly.’

Knowledge Point: The value property item fáyn ‘be fine, nice, correct’ is frequently found in clause-final position to provide manner modification. The use of fáyn in this way is conventionalised to such an extent that it may be considered an adverb with its own established meaning of ‘nicely, properly, in the right way’ (a similar case is made for bád ‘extremely’, cf. \ref{ex:key:897}–\ref{ex:key:898} further below):
Content 1: \gll A de sɔ́ri \textbf{bád.} | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV feel.sorry extremely | \glt ‘I really feel sorry.’
Content 2: \gll E fáyn \textbf{bád,} e fáyn \textbf{bád.} | \gls 3SG.SBJ be.fine extremely 3SG.SBJ be.fine extremely | \glt ‘She is really beautiful, she is really beautiful.’

Knowledge Point: Another idiosyncratic way of expressing manner modification is through the lexicalised reduplication haydháyd ‘secretly’ \REF{ex:key:878}:
Content 1: \gll Chico, yu dɔ́n chɔ́p=an \textbf{haydháyd}. | \gls boy 2SG PRF eat=3SG.OBJ secretly | \glt ‘Man, you’ve eaten it secretly.’

Knowledge Point: Further, Pichi employs the adverb-deriving suffix \textit{{}-wán} \textsc{‘adv’} to form manner adverbs \REF{ex:key:879}, and the generic noun stáyl ‘style’ \REF{ex:key:880} in order to form manner-denoting adverbial NPs in clause-final position:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}s dɛn nɔ́ba bin sí plantí, dɛn bin chɔ́p=an \textbf{rɔ́n-wán}. | \gls as 3PL NEG.PRF PST see plantain 3PL PST eat=3SG.OBJ wrong-ADV | \glt ‘Since they had never seen plantain before, they ate it the wrong way.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn tíf di mɔní \textbf{síkrit} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3PL steal DEF money secret style | \glt ‘They stole the money secretly.’

Knowledge Point: For one part, biclausal structures are common in providing modifications of circumstance. Compare the following adverbial clauses introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’ \REF{ex:key:882} and sé ‘\textsc{quot}’ \REF{ex:key:883}:
Content 1: \gll E gó na wók \textbf{wé} e \textbf{klín}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ go LOC work SUB 3SG.SBJ be.clean | \glt ‘She went to work clean.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Another common way of providing modification to a clause is by means of depictive secondary predication (cf. also \sectref{sec:11.3}). In the depictive adjunct in \REF{ex:key:884}, the secondary predicate nékɛd ‘be naked’ provides information about the state of the subject e \textsc{‘3sg.sbj’,} while the situation denoted by kɔmɔ́t ‘come out’ unfolds:\is{secondary predicates}
Content 1: \gll E kɔmɔ́t na rúm \textbf{nékɛd}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ come.out LOC room be.naked | \glt ‘He left the room naked.’

Knowledge Point: Modifications of circumstance may also be provided through nominal depictives that come in the guise of prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases} introduced by wet ‘with’ \REF{ex:key:885} and lɛk ‘like’ \REF{ex:key:886}:
Content 1: \gll E pút di bɔ́tul pan di tébul \textbf{wet} \textbf{di} \textbf{mɔ́t} \textbf{dɔ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ put DEF bottle pan DEF table with DEF mouth down | \glt ‘He put the bottle on the table upside-down.’
Content 2: \gll Pero mi mamá kán acepta di pikín \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{mi} \textbf{brɔ́da} \textbf{in} \textbf{pikín}. | \gls but 1SG.POSS mother PFV accept DEF child like 1SG brother 3SG.POSS child | \glt ‘But my mother accepted the child as my brother’s child.’

Knowledge Point: The similative collocation wók lɛk dɔ́kta functions as a nominal depictive \REF{ex:key:888} (cf. \sectref{sec:11.3} for an extensive discussion of verbal depictives in secondary predications). A similative lɛk in \REF{ex:key:889} translates as ‘around’:
Content 1: \gll Di cubana húman de \textbf{wók} \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{dɔ́kta} na Malábo. | \gls DEF Cuban woman IPFV work like doctor LOC PLACE | \glt ‘The Cuban woman works as a doctor in Malabo.’
Content 2: \gll Yu fít gí mí \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{dos} \textbf{mil} só? | \gls 2SG can give 1SG.INDP like two thousand like.that | \glt ‘Can you give me around two thousand?’

Knowledge Point: Some relations of modification that habitually re-occur tend to be expressed through verb-noun compounds. For example, the depictive secondary predication in \REF{ex:key:891} is more often rendered by \REF{ex:key:892}:
Content 1: \gll E dríng di \textbf{watá} \textbf{kól}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ drink DEF water be.cold | \glt ‘She drank the water cold.’
Content 2: \gll E dríng \textbf{kol-watá}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ drink cold.CPD-water | \glt ‘She drank cold water.’

Knowledge Point: Degree modification may also be realised on the suprasegmental level. Vowel-length\-en\-ing and extra-high pitch may indicate a larger amount of intensity, extent, or dimension of a referent, which is generally a property item or an adverbial. The only syllable of the property item kól ‘be cold’ in \REF{ex:key:893} is pronounced with an extra-high tone and lengthened. The phonetic transcription is provided in squared brackets:
Content 1: \gll Pero wé a kin tɔ́ch in fút, in hán dé, na só dɛn \textbf{kó.ól}~\textup{[k\H{o}::l]}. | \gls but SUB 1SG.SBJ HAB touch 3SG.POSS leg 3SG.POSS hand there FOC like.that 3PL cold.EMP | \glt ‘But when I would touch his foot (and) his hand, they were so extremely cold.’

Knowledge Point: Vowel lengthening and extra-high tone are conventionalised with the preposition sóté ‘until’. Both phenomena always occur when sóté is employed as a clause-final temporal adverb with the meaning ‘for a long time’ or a degree adverb with the meaning ‘extremely’ \REF{ex:key:894}:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn kéch=an dɛn bít=an \textbf{sóté.e}~\textup{[s\H{o}t\H{e}::]}. | \gls 3PL catch=3SG.OBJ 3PL beat=3SG.OBJ until.EMP | \glt ‘They caught him and beat the hell out of him.’

Knowledge Point: Suprasegmental degree modification is performed in accordance with the syllable structure of the modified word. Monosyllabic words bear an extra-high tone over their H-toned syllable. If the syllable ends in a vowel, liquid, or nasal, it may also be lengthened. Two examples for this pattern are kól ‘be cold’ in \REF{ex:key:893} above and fá ‘be far’ in \REF{ex:key:895} below.
Content 1: \gll Pero wé a kin tɔ́ch in fút, in hán dé, na só dɛn \textbf{kó.ól}~\textup{[k\H{o}::l]}. | \gls but SUB 1SG.SBJ HAB touch 3SG.POSS leg 3SG.POSS hand there FOC like.that 3PL cold.EMP | \glt ‘But when I would touch his foot (and) his hand, they were so extremely cold.’
Content 2: \gll Wántɛn a skía, e sé “nó skía, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.áwe}~\textup{[fá:we]}, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.á}~\textup{[fá::]}.” | \gls suddenly 1SG.SBJ be.scared 3SG.SBJ QUOT NEG be.scared 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP | \glt ‘Suddenly, I became scared, he said “don’t be scared, I come from very far away, I come from very far”.’

Knowledge Point: The H-toned syllable of a bisyllabic word may also be lengthened if it ends in a vowel or liquid. Compare fawe ‘be far’ in \REF{ex:key:895} below. Both fá and fáwe in \REF{ex:key:895} are additionally emphasised by means of an extra-high tone:
Content 1: \gll Wántɛn a skía, e sé “nó skía, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.áwe}~\textup{[fá:we]}, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.á}~\textup{[fá::]}.” | \gls suddenly 1SG.SBJ be.scared 3SG.SBJ QUOT NEG be.scared 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP | \glt ‘Suddenly, I became scared, he said “don’t be scared, I come from very far away, I come from very far”.’
Content 2: \gll Wántɛn a skía, e sé “nó skía, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.áwe}~\textup{[fá:we]}, a kɔmɔ́t \textbf{fá.á}~\textup{[fá::]}.” | \gls suddenly 1SG.SBJ be.scared 3SG.SBJ QUOT NEG be.scared 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP 1SG.SBJ come.out far.EMP | \glt ‘Suddenly, I became scared, he said “don’t be scared, I come from very far away, I come from very far”.’

Knowledge Point: In contrast, vowel-lengthening for degree modification is not attested with mono- or bisyllabic words with word-final H-toned syllables that end in plosives or fricatives. With this group of words, we only find emphatic extra-high tone or other types of degree modification. For example, in \REF{ex:key:896}, the property item bíg ‘be big’ is modified for degree by repetition and the H-tone over both iterations is raised:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Property items that do not denote dimension or a physical property and adverbs that do not denote a manner or degree are not usually modified suprasegmentally in this way. One way of providing degree modification to other types of words is by means of the value property item bád in clause-final position. For example, in \REF{ex:key:897} the property item bád ‘bad’ is employed as a degree adverb with the meaning ‘extremely’.
Content 1: \gll A de sɔ́ri \textbf{bád.} | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV feel.sorry extremely | \glt ‘I really feel sorry.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:898}, bád modifies fáyn ‘(be) fine’. The example shows that bád retains nothing of its lexical meaning of ‘be bad’ when employed in this function. It is a true degree adverbial and may also modify a verb which is the antonym of its lexical source:
Content 1: \gll E fáyn \textbf{bád,} e fáyn \textbf{bád.} | \gls 3SG.SBJ be.fine extremely 3SG.SBJ be.fine extremely | \glt ‘She is really beautiful, she is really beautiful.’

Knowledge Point: The sentence-final particle ó may also provide degree modification to a sentence \REF{ex:key:899}. The various functions of this particle are covered in detail in \sectref{sec:12.2.4}:
Content 1: \gll E hád \textbf{ó}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ be.hard SP | \glt ‘It’s really difficult.’
